¿Qué es lo que yo quiero? En esta sesión intentaré escribir un poco sobre como yo me siento ahora mismo de la manera más honesta y transparente. No le prestaré atención a los typos. Hoy estamos a 17 de febrero del 2021. Llevo ya un tiempo pensando sobre que quiero hacer. Por un lado, tengo la opción de quedarme en Barcelona, mi hogar por los últimos cuatro años, casi cinco. Por otro lado, he pensado que toca un cambio y creo que el sitio ideal para hacer este cambio sería Puerto Rico. Por uno porque yo no tengo muchas ganas de querer vivir en Estados Unidos. Me siento más a gusto viviendo con mi familia y quiero poder estar ahí para ellos. El problema es que no tengo muy claro que es lo que yo estaría haciendo en Puerto Rico. He estado en contacto con varias agencias de publicidad, pero por otro lado no se si es algo que yo quiera estar haciendo. Yo creo que es un trabajo que va en contra de mi bienestar emocional y uno que requiere largas horas y reuniones interminables y redundantes. Yo rápidamente pierdo el interés el momento que siento que estoy perdiendo el tiempo. Una de las cosas que he pensado es si yo fuera a regresar a Puerto Rico que podría estar haciendo. Una de las ideas que tengo en mi mente es este deseo de querer «regalarme» una carrera y un trabajo. Esto sería desarrollando una empresa que se dedicaría a documentar la complejidad y vitalidad de la cultura puertorriqueña y su diaspora. El diferencial aquí sería que sería una publicación en inglés. Una de las cosas que me interesa es cultivar un espacio donde la diaspora puertorriqueña y local pueda interactuar. Yo creo que hay un interés no sólo de puertorriqueños viviendo en los Estados Unidos pero también de estadounidenses que no tiene mucha idea de la vida y situaciones que están pasando en la isla. Mi intención no es ser la típica empresa mediática que produce contenido 24/7 para consumir. Sino que sería algo más lento y algo que iría con la intención de profundizar más allá de las cosas que suceden en el día a día. Esto suena todo chulo y bonito pero la pregunta que esto me genera es, ¿Cómo se va financiar este proyecto? Para crear un argumento para este tipo de proyecto también necesitaría crear una propuesta económica de como se va mantener. Honestamente, no tengo idea. Una sería buscar auspiciadores y crear contenido para ellos para mejorar su imagen y mejorar sus ventas. Esto lo haría más fácil para que está publicación sea accessible para todos. Otra sería crear un modelo de suscripción donde los suscritores sean los único con acceso a este material. Otra sería crear contenido totalmente gratuito y trabajar en otra cosa a medida que esto vaya creciendo. Esto es un poco la idea que tengo en mi mente. Ahora, la siguiente pregunta sería ¿qué contenido voy a encontrar cuando visite la página? Buena pregunta. Yo creo que las cosas que podrían encontrar aquí son artículos de larga redacción hablando sobre los hospitales públicos en la isla y como se atienden casos de violencia. Otro sería los que fundaron Jóvenes de Puerto Rico en Riesgo y entrar un poco en sobre como es que Puerto Rico tiene la incidencia más alta de homicidios entre los jóvenes, más allá que en Estados Unidos. Otra sería conocer como fue que Filiberto Ojeda y su pandilla lograron robar un camión de Wells Fargo en los 80s y como fue que acabaron en Cuba, supuestamente. Otra idea sería las diferencias entre un joven en una escuela pública y otro en una escuela privada. La intención sería la misma, documentar la complejidad y vitalidad de la cultura puertorriqueña y su diaspora. El problema es que esto requiere un esfuerzo monumental. Primero habría que crear la marca y la narrativa. Luego habría que crear todo el contenido ya sea lo visual y la redacción, y luego habría que hacer todo esto con la intención de que alguien este dispuesto a pagar y que vea el interés en esto. Son muchos obstáculos y no hay manera de saber si esto tenga algo de éxito. Mi otra opción es quedarme en Barcelona. Si me quedo en Barcelona lo ideal sería trabajar con Domestika. Es algo seguro ya que es una empresa que está creciendo muchísimo y es un sitio que yo me puedo ver creciendo profesionalmente. Pero también entiendo que esto no es la única opción. Podría cambiar a autónomo y empezar a trabajar con otras empresas aquí. Entonces yo ahora mismo veo estás dos vías. Lo único que me aguanta de regresar a Puerto Rico es que si me voy de Barcelona perderé mi residencia y no podré volver. Esto quiere decir que si lo de Puerto Rico no sale bien pues «tough titties». Es un riesgo. Si Puerto Rico no sale bien pues tendría que buscar un trabajo y esto no tiene ninguna garantía que aprendería algo nuevo (o quizás si) y no tiene ninguna garantía que estaría ganando más o que mi calidad de vida este por encima de lo que estoy viviendo ahora. Si Puerto Rico no sale bien eso quiere decir que tendré que regresar un poco a como estaban las cosas antes, aunque he madurado, prefiero no tener que vivir por eso de nuevo. Si Puerto Rico sale bien, por otro lado, esto quiere decir que habré realizado un sueño que siempre he tenido. Que he podido contribuir a algo que realmente me interesa y algo que siempre he querido hacer. Si Puerto Rico sale bien, tendré mi propia empresa y podré cultivar una vida para mí. Yo lo veo así ahora mismo. ¿Qué más puedo decir? Yo por un lado no creo que volveré con Ariana. La extraño y es una mujer que me ha dado mucho y me ha hecho muy feliz y es una persona maravillosa, pero luego de ocho años de intentar y fracasar creo que llega un momento donde uno dice que mejor no continuar siguiendo esto. Yo amo Ariana, creo que es una persona con una capacidad de amar enorme, pero también pienso que es una persona que no está bien y que tiene que aprender a respetar los límites de otros, que tiene que entender que el vomito emocional hacia otra persona tiene sus consecuencias y que las cosas tienen que ser una conversación y diálogo para que puedan florecer. Yo me sentía muchas veces estancado porque no sabía que podía hacer para sanar sus heridas y sentía que ella me estaba haciendo a mi responsable por su malestar y eso a cambio me estaba haciendo más incómodo y no me permitía que yo pudiese ser la persona que ella necesitaba en esos momentos. Yo la amo sobretodo porque es de esas personas que me hace reír y me lleno la vida de propósito. Pero a la misma vez sentía que estaba perdiendo mi identidad al punto de no saber que estaba bien y que estaba mal. Esto es otro factor en lo de regresar a Puerto Rico. Sabiendo que Ariana estará ahí, si yo voy a Puerto Rico que va pasar, ¿regresamos? ¿somos amigos? ¿yo me quedo y luego ella se va? Hay muchos factores envuelto aquí. No niego que la extraño. Pero así es. Un factor a favor es que Steven estará en Puerto Rico y tendrá un hijo o hija. Otro factor es que podré compartir con papa, aunque me saca un poco de quicio, puedo aprovechar lo que seguramente será sus últimos años de vida. Esto no es decir que el va morir mañana pero ya a los 75 y con la dieta que ha tenido yo puedo decir que no creo que le queda mucho y eso no lo digo de manera cínico sino que es algo que va pasar y me tengo que preparar para ella. También Titi Mare, se que no le queda mucho en esta tierra y me gustaría poder compartir con ella. Tío Johny también, están todos envejeciendo y creo que cada uno ha tenido una vida súper interesante y me gustaría estar ahí para documentarlo. Entonces, ¿qué va pasar si me quedo en Barcelona? Lo bueno es que tendré mis mejores amigos aquí, se que estará Akash, estará Matt, Yonah, Duncan, Saskia, Jay, Blanca, Bia, Marek, y tengo mis amistades como Eli, Marta, Pau, Harry y compañía. En Puerto Rico se que puedo contar con Steven, Manon, Antonio, Isabel, Roxana, Luisfran, Kenny, Kevin, Felo, Che. Tengo 33 años y la pregunta es que quiero hacer. ¿Cómo quiero pasar mis 33? La verdad es que la contestación es bastante sencilla. Lo difícil es hacerlo. Yo ahora mismo he luchado como un animal para poder estar aquí en Barcelona y me rejode que tenga que seguir luchando para poder quedarme aquí y que no tenga ahorros y que sea tan complicado poder hacer las gestiones aquí. Por eso no quiero desperdiciar este momento y lo que quiero es poder renovar la residencia y así puedo tener más tranquilidad. Con esto yo podría empezar a trabajar aquí y luego de un tiempo regresar a Puerto Rico y darle unos meses a ver si este plan funciona o no. Me gusta Barcelona. Me siento afortunado de haber podido llegar a este punto y sabiendo que he podido incorporarme un lugares muy chulos para trabajar, sobretodo cuando yo he sido muy reacio a trabajar. Al día de hoy no me encanta trabajar mucho, no veo el valor en tener que trabajar fines de semanas y horas largas para uno mantener lo más mínimo para sobrevivir. Me parece un abuso. Y eso es otra cosa que va encontrar de regresar a Puerto Rico, porque se que ahí me van a exprimir de forma que no me va compensar como yo quiero. Entonces eso es un factor bien grande porque yo se que si lo de este proyecto no sale pues caigo en eso. Y caigo en volver a vivir en casa y caigo en aquellos patrones y caigo en cuestiones de autoestima porque me preguntaré que hago yo con 33-34 años de edad todavía viviendo en casa cuando mis amigos se han mudado, comprado casas, se han casado y han tenidos hijos, y luego yo voy a intentar de luchar ese pensamiento diciendo algo bien anormal como ¿pero ellos estarán felices? ¿están felices con las mentiras que sus padres les han metido a ellos? y entonces iré en este bucle. Eso es un poco lo que va pasar. Pero luego revisaré las lecciones de Pema Chödrön y diré que el sufricimiento que yo he sufrido lo han sufrido todos y forma parte de la experiencia humana y luego con una meditación de 15 o 20 minutos porque no puedo aguantar más sin tener que volver a mirar mi puto iPhone regresaré y apaciguaré ese malestar aunque sea por unos 4 minutos y luego volvera el ruido de la mente sin cesar. Por eso es que yo me veo ahora mismo quedándome aquí en Barcelona. La realidad es que no tengo muchas opciones. Aparte de Domestika, no me llama mucho la atención otros sitios así que esto para mi es la única opción que yo tengo. Si lo de Domestika no cae pues volveré a Puerto Rico y me iré full con el proyecto que tengo en mente que probablemente no me dará con que comer pero será una gran contribución a la diversidad cultural del país. ¿Quién sabe? Está sesión me ha ayudado bastante y yo espero que si sigo escribiendo así que quizás tal vez pueda llegar a un sitio que me pueda influir las decisiones que yovaya a tomar en el futuro cercano. Me gusta esta idea de vomitar todo lo que yo estoy sintiendo en el momento porque creo que genera un momentum y una frenesí que me hace poder hacer un exorcismo de todo lo que está pasando ahora mismo. Otro factor grande es el hecho de que quiero formar una nueva relación y quiero salir ocn alguien y me interesa mucho las europeas porque son bien guapas y creo que eso también es otro factor. No tiene que ser europeas verdad pero aquí hay muchas chicas guapas que le quiero comer el coño bien rico como Claudia pero se que eso no creo que vaya a pasar pero aquí estamos.

Reading is a cognitively demanding activity. When you [[read your unfinished story to figure out what happens next]], it helps to appreciate the time someone is willing to invest to read and review your work. The person who is willing to read your work is giving their time and attention, so honor that exchange by giving something worthy of their time. Pressfield says, "when you understand that nobody wants to read your shit, your mind becomes powerfully concentrated. You begin to understand that writing/reading is... a transaction."
Pressfield, Steven. The War of Art: Break Through the Blocks and Win Your Inner Creative Battles. , 2012. Print. #[[Steven Pressfield]]

children.content: The pressure to make the most use of our time tends to come from forces outside our control. blocks.page-name: trusts are used to avoid paying taxes

children.content: > Jersey’s speciality is the trust. Trusts are said to date back to the Middle Ages, when knights went away on a crusade and wanted to preserve control of their property for their wives and children. The knights gave their assets to a trusted retainer on the condition that any income they generated would continue to flow to their children. This principle has multiple applications in all legal systems based on Britain’s, including one of the great offshore tricks, since it separates the legal ownership of something from the benefits it provides. A condo may be in New York, and you may live in it, but you do not own it; it is owned by a trust company in Jersey which has a legal arrangement to pass it on to your grandchildren. The advantages of this from the perspective of a potential Moneylander are clear: if you no longer own something, you cannot be taxed on it, only on the revenue that it generates. Trusts are central to ‘succession planning’ – the euphemism for when rich people dodge inheritance tax – and Jersey lawyers are very good at setting them up.
Bullough, Oliver. Moneyland: Why Thieves And Crooks Now Rule The World And How To Take It Back. Profile Books, 2019. #[[Oliver Bullough]]

Note-taking works best when the note is about one thing. **==Make a note that captures the entirety of that thing.==** This makes it easier to **form new connections across different topics and contexts.** If your notes are too broad, you might fail to notice when you come across a new idea. On the other hand, if your notes are too fragmented, you'll likely fail to make new connections. The golden rule here is to make the note about one thing. [[Look for the explanation that makes it obvious]]  so that your note is reusable in a different context. This is why Andy Matushak sees evergreen notes as the equivalent of an API.
An API because evergreen notes focus on being atomic allows you to reuse it in different topics and contects.

Quede con Ariana el sábado. Estaba en una barbacoa en casa de Adam (que es el periodista) que vive con alguien más de betahaus que ahora no me acuerdo. Habíamos venido de casa de Yonah, que estaba con Blanca (2) y con Bia. Yonah hizo el estofado que se tardó 24 horas en hacer y tenía buena textura pero realmente estaba soso y con sal no brego. Esa dinámica sexual. Fuimos al bar donde hicieron los beta awards y no había nadie. Pero estábamos bebiendo entre los 4. La alemana se fue luego Sara y quede yo ahí con Ariana. Ariana me estaba hablando con el chichi y papo y bebé y ven a mi mi amor. Que me pone bien bellaco la verdad. Soy una presa asequible.
Bueno de ahí quedamos y empezamos a besar y el resto realmente fue medio nube. Pero chingamos el sábado. Yo me vine como dos veces y ella nada. Pero el domingo por la mañana intentamos de nuevo y ella se vino y yo también, como dos veces de nuevo. Digo que el resto es una nube porque nos pasamos el día juntos. El plan era ir a brunch pero nos pasamos el día en la cama besando y chingando. Como conejos. Y durmiendo. Y luego de eso fuimos a buscar brunch y fuimos en moto la desayunaría. Yo pedí el manchito algo y ella otra cosa, un omelette de vegetal con waffles pero los waffles sabían a cartón viejo y el mesero parece que no sabía que estaba haciendo. De ahí volvimos al piso andando y el plan era quedar en la noche con Huss y Sara. Ariana me dijo que no me podía besar porque aún tenía su situación - su situación siendo que está comprometida con un mexicano y que supuestamente iban a quedar en Cancún pero algo paso con el que resultado que Ariana ahora va sola a Cancún. Y ahora mismo está en un avión a punto de aterrizar en una ciudad que nunca ha estado y sola. Y todo sabiendo que no va regresar a Barcelona y que ha dejado su trabajo y su vida aquí para algo totalmente nuevo con una empresa grande y sin crédito o apartamento con una relación que parece que no va bien así que si, bastante nervios debería de tener. Conoci a Omar y a Pam, yo pensaba que ella era la hermana con el chico con quien se Iba a casar así que estaba bastante nervioso. Ariana me enviaba mensajes y yo le contestaba. Yo dije que la iba a llevar a su piso  pero no lo tenía claro y de ahí resultó que si. Nos fuimos juntos. El lunes fui al trabajo y ella a la del y me había dicho que si estaba bien si se quedaba que le dije que si. Aún no estaba claro de todo. Luego me dijo que si. Luego se enfadó porque no le había contestado. Pero estaba bien. En la noche fuimos a Mosquito con su amiga Julia su novio Caros Navarro y Sara yo y Ariana. De ahí compartimos comida y me lleve bien con Carlos le dije que estaba en Firma y el se alegro porque conoce a Dani Ávila y que jugaba en freelance United. Hablamos bastante y comimos mochi. El martes fue la ultima noche que pase con Ariana. Que sali del trabajo y el plan era ir al parque pero fuimos al piso y de ahí fuimos a la bodega al lado a tomar cava y luego a bar brutal donde nos recibió la jeva de Dani en el piso donde vivía en Sant Antoni. Fuimos ahí y Ariana pago casi todo me sentí mal por eso. Fuimos al piso y follamos bien duro. Luego de una crítica de ella que quería más power y se lo di.

El miércoles por la noche fui a buscarla a Choc y estaba con Estaban que era medio Debbie downer oni estaba contento. Luego llego Huss fuimos al piso de ella bajamos y de ahí y hablamos un buen rato. Ella tiene esta forma de verme donde ella se ve totalmente vulnerable y es una mirada como si me estuviera mostrando su alma. Me encanta que tenemos esta dinámica de juego y que ella siempre está buscando reírse y se ríe fácilmente o al menos conmigo y me lo paso bien cabron con ella. Nunca hay un momento aburrido. Y es inteligente y tiene un apetito intelectual que me encanta y que es algo que me parece bastante raro.

Tenemos una historia juntos y compartimos muchos de los mismos intereses en parte porque hemos vivido más o menos lo mismo, en cuanto donde nos criamos, donde nos educamos, donde nos escapamos, y como bregamos con todo eso.

Estoy escribiendo porque estoy buscando el “pero” pero el “pero” no lo encuentro. No me siento apegado de manera poco saludable donde tengo celos y me entra una ansiedad por no saber si esta con alguien o no. Eso definitivamente que aún lo siento pero cuando lo reconozco me repito la palabra “ego” y continuo viviendo mi vida. Y no se si eso es cambio pero no permito que me nuble el pensamiento. Creo que esa es la mejor forma que lo puedo describir. Y estoy fumando y es lo que siento ahora.

Cada vez que follaba con Ariana el tema de preñarla y darle un bebé surgía. Y yo se que ella quiere eso y sabe que eso a la misma vez lo excita y me excita a mi también. Y que esta vez me lo podría disfrutar sin asustarme. Pues así es. Luego hablo de que si le iba a proponer matrimonio. Pues así está. Lo pienso pero no me lo imagino. Una relación on and off en estás situación parece predeterminado a no funcionar. Si se acabo se acabo por alguna razón, right?

Pues no lo sé. No lo he vivido pero tampoco no quiero ilusionarme sin hay dolor también. Ariana se disculpo y se automenosprecia a veces. Pero así es. Me dio crítica que me dijo que no tenía ambición pero le dije todo lo que había hecho y que no entendía, luego le reformule y le pregunté que si se refería a asertivo que no soy asertivo y dijo que si y ahí estoy de acuerdo hasta cierto punto. Y se aquí lo iré trabajando.
Bueno besamos y lloro y yo llore pero nos fuimos bien. Y ahora seguimos hablando y me envío varías fotos sexy y las tengo ahí guardada para hacerme una pajita más tarde.
Bueno eso es todo por ahora. Seguiré escribiendo. Clear thoughts clear mind.

Having an ideal reader can help give the confidence to put words together and tell a story. The excitement from seeing that special someone react genuinely with laugher or shudder in fear from a particular paragraph or chapter. In his memoir, Stephen King writes "I think that every novelist has a single ideal reader; that at various points during the composition of a story, the writer is thinking, 'I wonder what she will think when she reads this part". Writers have a desire to tell stories, but they may lack the confidence to do it. An ideal reader gives that encouragement, because all that is required to become a writer is for someone to believe in you.
Think of the lines you write for someone as a secret message in a bottle to address someone. [[writing is about sharing your darlings]].
But more than having someone to believe in you, an [[read your unfinished story to figure out what happens next]].

I’m sitting on my bed, watching videos about flimflammers, mountebanks, sophists and frauds. James Randi is the kind of hard-nosed scientists who must get a rush from calling out the so-called psychics BS. with the horoscope and popularity of astrology apps, it seems like hope is the hottest commodity right now. Why can’t we just accept nihilism? We all worship something, but why does that weigh so much in the outcome of my life? To deceive or be deceived? I understand life would be numb and boring as hell if it were not. It would be very different if that were the case. I love magic, for instance. I know its bs, but I believe in its ability to be profoundly psychological. With Nietzsche’s claim of “God is dead!” or Gott ist tot! (I hope I nailed the German!) The question of meaning, as in the question of death, was passed on to philosophy. Death became the muse of philosophy. But I’m astounded by the magic. David Blaine, for instance, is someone that I just get sucked into. It’s literally a drug, your brain is completely hooked on what is happening. Watching magic is amazing, but observing yourself getting duped into magic is even more amazing. Because the brain acts in a very mechanical way. Why does it react that way? We haven’t seen it, but we need to believe that we haven’t seen it. This is an absolute mind fuck. We need to believe, of course, but it’s almost like taking candy from a baby, by tapping into that nerve for personal profit. This is a paradox, no? Our need to believe while punishing others for fooling us. It’s a clear difference, one reminds you that it is a trick, while the other deliberately hides it. That’s the difference. So if we take it to how does this relate to me? My question would be, how evil am I allowed to be? The difference is letting them know beforehand (e.g. stand up comedians), that what they are seeing is an act. The question here becomes how far can we pull this. Andy Kaufman pushed it to the absolute limit. He was an anarchist. Other people want to focus on morality to establish order. Order requires a sense of madness because life is chaos. This is fact. Entropy, Newton’s second law of thermodynamics, everything moves towards disorder. Can there be something else that happens then? Something that happens after the heat death of the universe? The answer is no. And that is OK! Death is death. I can actually feel myself, I can almost feel like my brain is struggling to accept this. Like my knee-jerk reaction is “I don’t know!” Like there’s another voice, that’s hope. Hope. Survival matters. Focus is your key. Honing your focus. I feel a need right now to distract myself from what I’m thinking, I want to check my phone, I want to think about something else. But I feel I’ve hit on a nerve. I can let go of a thought too. The only problem is I don’t want to distract myself by shutting down the mind. Writing is important, because I want to have a high quality of thinking. What exactly does that mean? I want to be able to make decisions that… Why a better world? This seems to be the default response. I almos feel like code that’s been programmed. Again, I know this is BS, I’m not taking it as evidence for belief. This is why we need fiction, why we need art. Because art is about mortality. Belief is madness. It is a type of madness. You need to shed old survival gear and morph into the new survival gear. You can continue shedding the old shit, that should be the focus of your life.

My dream is to get rid of advertising. I was thinking about how we should get paid for content or material we provide. Some of us already do. Whoever gets subscribe button and receives sponsors or advertisers. This system works to the best of its ability. It traces you and groups you into different categories where it can then target you based on a pool of shared interests. It understands you so can make bets on how likely you are going to purchase this targeted ad. This system works, but I feel like it only works thanks to brilliant engineering from Facebook, Google, and Apple. They are hard to visualize as statues, but they are massive emblems that activated communication with the world like plugging in christmas lights. We are IKEA furnished, Apple geared, and Google commoditized. We think we are unique, that our lives hold meaning, but this is a massive con. We are no better or no worse than everybody else. Pain is real. Pain is absolutely real. Pain is buried in our fear. Fear of going hungry prompts me to eat food. The need to write is prompted by fear of being alone with my thoughts. I know, they are just thoughts. I would say that I lough kind of rough play, like this standing over the edge see who can push the farthest. It’s so seductive. I bet you can’t do this. You can’t do this because if you did, you would die. But another person does it, and because you think, you are just seeing a reflection of yourself, but you are seeing that this “you” you are projecting to David Blaine, has died, has gone to the underworld, and has come back alive. You need to know everything about it. How was it? How did it go? How did you do it? Is it real? Of course it’s real. The message you hear in your head is, “of course it’s real that you went to hell and back. It’s completely real!” And that is how David Blaine sells hope to the hopeless. He is not deceiving you with a trick, your mind is deceiving you with a trick. That’s the magic trick. And to his credit, it is fucking brilliant. You’ve come out as an entertainer, done something incredible and more importantly, visceral (that’s the ticket to the passage to hell, chu!). And you say no way, it can’t be! And your mind’s knee-jerk reaction is correct, it can’t be! But then everyone around you seems to agree, and your brain must rationalize what just happened and because you can’t make sense of it, your brain begins to weave in together a story so that the “truth” will come out, and tell you. This happened because he has psychic powers. This happened because he did speak to the ghosts. Cold reading combined with the desire for approval and to be correct in presence of others. Are we smarter today or before?

Yes, but today’s magic tricks are not done by humans in a stage, but by dead code. It’s like a virus, it’s code that is not alive but can only replicate itself by the number of hosts (i.e. scammed). They are highly common, I would assume. Get rid of advertising. Why not just make a universal fund that people get a basic living wage? No one would work. This is the knee-jerk reaction, and I don’t know whether if this is true or not, but the statement seems to have some truth to it. Have there been studies to show what would the reaction be? Is the study a reliable predictor for society at large? What are the negative consequences of it? What would be the positive consequences of it? These are not horribly difficult questions, and I don’t know the answer to them. Politicians are magicians in this way as well. Selling hope to the hopeless. It is worse because they are not letting you know that what they are doing is an act. Only those who swear by the constitution deserve to act, because it is an honorable role, and it is an important role. Quacks like Trump deserve to be imprisoned for such beliefs. I would like to think of the worst thing I would say here that would prompt a Federal investigation? Like I want to test how free my limits of speech are. And whatever gets you arrested or locked up, then that’s where the limit is. Criminals, therefore, are social justice warriors, for good or for bad, for attempting to expand the limit of speech.

Pendo Guidelines 

Main user experience concepts you must bear in mind

* Avoid friction: users may feel threatened if we push them to take some action, it’s a kind of “losing control” experience. Nudging can be a powerful technique. 
* Earn trust: users need to trust some application or be motivated enough before asking for anything else, if not, it can be disrupting and gain some kind of mistrust. 
* Progressive disclosure: think about the learning curve. Starting from the basic and more highlighted aspects and, once they learned, start showing more advanced information. 

Main components and characteristics
Less disruptive to More disruptive 

* Tooltips
    * Are not used in Pendo guides 
    * Contextual brief help
    * Displayed with hover
* Popovers
    * Contextual information is connected to an element. 
    * Displayed with triggers or page events. 
* Non-modals
    * Promote actions that are not critical to the service
    * Displayed force at screen edges but users can interact with the background 
* Modals
    * Keep users’ attention so it must be worth it. 
    * Displayed force and users cannot interact with the background 

Popover
* Used for
    * Providing additional contextual information about a single element
    * Providing information that doesn’t need to be shown repeatedly 
* Not used for
    * Content is vital for task completion, keep the info on screen instead
    * Users need to refer back to the content frequently, it is also better to keep the info on the screen. 

Popovers are highlighted but not annoying: you can choose the direction of the popover, so keep in mind not to cover important parts of the page. 

When do you use the popover? Walkthrough 
When there is a new product or update which includes more than one feature. 

When do you use the popover?  Walkthrough
When first users decide to use it, so they can be asked with a previous model or non-modal. 
When users can see the value of that feature. Also, if the feature requires having more data or interactions, it’s better to show it latter or think of alternatives (demo video, sample projects, …)

For example, if users don’t have projects created, it doesn’t have sense to focus on template features on a walkthough.

How many steps for the popover?  Walkthrough
* From 3 to 4 steps Use auto-driven walkthroughs (users must take action) up to 5 steps.

What are the steps to include in a popover?  Walkthrough
* Features that are critical for the process. If we highlight non-critical features it can be heavy-handed and overbearing. Bear in mind that we’re in the onboarding process, advanced features can be shown later. 
For walkthrough items: 
Title 
* No more than one line
* Action oriented (start with a verb)
* Focus on the benefits and what the user can achieve. 
Skip
* Always provide an exit button for those who are not interested. 

Description (write)
* No more than three lines
* Brief description of the feature itself 

Buttons
Use established copy buttons to maintain consistency 

Progress
* Be transparent and show users how much effort is going to take to complete the process. 

Aside from walkthrough 
Highlight feature popover

When to use highlight feature popover?
* There’s a contextual new feature or update we want to highlight.  
* Discover and learn more advanced features into the learning curve. 
* Overlooked features which goal is to be promoted 

Remember that big releases should be announced previously in a non-contextual behaviour using modal or non-modal on the dashboard, so all users will be up to date. 

When to use highlight feature popover?
* Always in a contextual situation, the arrow will also help to point out the location. Users will be using that feature so probably they will be more interested to start using it. 

What does the highlight feature popover CTA do?
* The main call-to-action skips the component, and users must close it and, then, decide if they want to go there or not.  
Non-modal

What is a non-modal?
A non-modal is a dialog component displayed on the edge of the screen with no overlay, so users can interact with the product.

What is a non-modal used for?
* Information which can be interesting for a concrete number of users, not all of them. 
* Ask for any kind of optional features or information users might be interested 
* Promote actions that are not critical to the service 

What is a non-modal not used for?
* Keeps user full attention, use modals instead  
Abuse of its usage. It keeps less attention than modals but if it’s used repeatedly and can be perceived as advertising and become a “blind zone”. 

When to use highlight features (non-modal)?
* Features or announcements that can be interesting for a concrete number of users. It’s less disrupting for the ones who don’t.  
* Promote concrete features without making it a big announcement.  

When to use highlight features for non-modal?
* Use it mostly contextual, users purpose is to use that service.  
Use it non-contextually if you want to have a higher promotion without disrupting use

What does a call-to-action do?

* Introduce a walkthrought  
* Direct contact with their account or a form 
* Other actions like scheduling a session, reading an article, go to another page... 
Non-modal non-critical action
When?
* Alert users about something. For example, there can be some free trial ending or a lower amount of credits.  
The action must be non-critical so it means that, if users don’t follow it, it's not going to affect negatively. 

When to use non-critical action (non-modal)?
* It can be non-contextual or contextual, depending on the purpose.  
Can be shown more than once with variations in order to convince users. Also, try not to abuse, it can feel too pushy.

Modal
What is a modal used for?
* Deserves users full attention, users can’t interact with the background
* Show meaningful information to the user in contextual or non-contextual environments. 

What is it not used for?
* Highlighting less important information can be disruptive. It increases a compulsory interaction, even for close it, so it must be worth it for them. 
* Mostly in non-contextual modals, provide information which can not be interesting to most of the users. 
* Show in the middle of a process, it is quite frustrating and users can end up losing focus (adds additional cognitive load) and spending more time recovering from it.  
* Appears too often, user must perceive these elements for super relevant and interesting information, if it doesn’t, can annoy the user even convert into a “blind component”.   

Here’s a NN Group video which shows some issues with modals through some examples: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ICfoXRRHTC0

Used to inform What’s new
It’s used as an informative component, it doesn’t prompt to take an action or go to another page. This applies to: 

* New products or big updates, which must include multiple features. Tiny ones might feel quite disruptive and frustrating.  
* A benefit available directly, avoid those that will be in the future, not available on that account. 
If we’re trying to promote user to go to a certain feature or page, better use a popover or a non-modal. 

Also, if we’re trying to join an event, subscribe or make an upsell we shouldn’t overwhelm them with lots of modals, users might feel that we’re pushing them.

Where?
Used it non-contextual situations, remember it must be something unique and exciting so interrupting it is worth it. 

What does the CTA do?
The main call-to-action skips the component as it’s an informative component. 


Modal used for Research engagement 
The goal of this type of component is to create a live intercept which allows us to take our clients as participants for product research. If you choose to use a modal: 

* Select a small segmented range of users that are suitable for this concrete user testing. Remember that you should not constantly interfere with your users.  

Where?
Use it non-contextual situation as it will go to the participant flow page.

What does a CTA do?
* If it’s a moderated test, the main call-to-action must go to scheduling participant flow.  
* If it’s a unmoderated test, the main call-to-action will launch that concrete test.  
* Always add a skip button to allow users not to take it.  


Modal used for Critical actions

IN which cased?
* Inform about a change of state which follows to decide on an action.  
* Avoid making mistakes or actions that will negatively affect users.  

For example, if we’re making a free trial, we should avoid disrupting components until the user has no option or, not making some changes, can affect some data. Before that happens, can feel as pushy. 

* Use it contextually if it’s related to a change of state.  
* Use it non-contextually if it can avoid some serious mistake to the user.

What Are Virtues? #card 
We can think of virtues as the as­pects of a per­son’s makeup that we ad­mire or as­so­ciate with good­ness; ba­si­cally, the qual­i­ties in peo­ple that make us want to be their friends—like brav­ery, tem­per­ance, gen­eros­ity, hon­esty, mag­na­nim­ity, and so on.

Aristotle defined virtues as the things that "cause [their] possessors to be in good state and perform their functions well." Virtues are things you acquire in your lifetime that make you unique and desirable. Things like bravery, temperance, generosity, honesty, magnanimity and so on are virtues that becomes part of who you are and gives you purpose. Think of a knife, for example. It's sharpness and blade strength are its virtues. Its purpose, therefore, is cutting things well.

Writing Style Guide

* Invite action. Help people make better decisions by using language that informs them and encourages them to do better research. 
* Respect. Every interaction is a transaction. We aim to build value for our users by showing respect and being constructive. 
* Educate. 


With every piece of content we publish, we aim to:
* Empower. Help people understand Mailchimp by using language that informs them and encourages them to make the most of our products. 
* Respect. Treat readers with the respect they deserve. Put yourself in their shoes, and don’t patronize them. Remember that they have other things to do. Be considerate and inclusive. Don’t market at people; communicate with them. 
* Educate. Tell readers what they need to know, not just what we want to say. Give them the exact information they need, along with opportunities to learn more. Remember that you’re the expert, and readers don’t have access to everything you know. 
* Guide. Think of yourself as a tour guide for our readers. Whether you’re leading them through our educational materials or a task in our app, communicate in a friendly and helpful way. 
* Speak truth. Understand Mailchimp's place in our users’ lives. Avoid dramatic storytelling and grandiose claims. Focus on our real strengths. 
In order to achieve those goals, we make sure our content is:
* Clear. Understand the topic you’re writing about. Use simple words and sentences. 
* Useful. Before you start writing, ask yourself: What purpose does this serve? Who is going to read it? What do they need to know? 
* Friendly. Write like a human. Don’t be afraid to break a few rules if it makes your writing more relatable. All of our content, from splashy homepage copy to system alerts, should be warm and human. 
* Appropriate. Write in a way that suits the situation. Just like you do in face-to-face conversations, adapt your tone depending on who you’re writing to and what you’re writing about.

blocks.page-name: creative writing combines literary and story talent

children.content: Creative writing calls on two skills, story talent and literary talent. Story talent is what converts daily existence into meaningful stories. It reveals what happens as a series of events. Literary talent, on the other hand, is what adds depth and substance to story by transforming everyday talk into dialogue to create an aesthetic for how characters in a story communicate. Literary talent works at the ground level and story talent works at the big picture level. Finding the thread that brings these two together is the magic of storytelling. Vocabulary is a key element of connecting these two because the choices of words help convey the personality and uniqueness of each character to give meaning to the events in a story.
Talent is important, but effort counts twice, and a [[focus on talent distracts us from the importance of effort]].
McKee, Robert. Story: Substance, Structure, Style and the Principles of Screenwriting. , 1997. #[[Robert McKee]]

The self

Humans do not truly See.
They see themselves trying to see.
Humans do not truly Do.
They see themselves trying to do.
Between a human and a thing lies a presence.
Between a human and a thing lies a prism.
This presence . . . this prism . . . is The Self.
There are always at least three presences in the room.
Never just two.

The question is not what to do with this Self.
The question is not how to get rid of this Self.
The question is not how to love this Self.
The question is not how to accept this Self.
The Questions are . . .
What is the cost of having a self?
Is it truly possible to live in peace in the presence of a self?
Is it truly possible to find freedom in the presence of a self?
Is it truly possible to live without conflict in the presence of a self?
Is it truly possible to arrive at clarity in the presence of a self?
Is it truly possible to create art and masterpieces in the presence of a self?
Is it truly possible to Live . . . in the presence of a self?

In the presence of a self, the slightest tremor feels like an earthquake.
In the presence of a self, there is constant anxiety and fear of what will happen to this self.
In the presence of a self, there is a 24-hour surveillance required to watch over this self.
In the presence of a self, there is a minute-by-minute appraisal of its condition and its feelings.
In the presence of a self, there is a lifelong struggle to improve it and adorn it.

Looking at the world through the eyes of a self, one sees only likes and dislikes.
These likes and dislikes give rise to “good” and “bad.”
Good and bad give rise to affinities and aversions.
Where there are affinities and aversions, there must be anxiety and fear.

It would not be wise to seek a solution to the problem of the self.
For the seeking of a solution will be yet another chase to garner more good feelings for the very self that one claims to be the problem.
There is no solution.

Does this mean that one must live in fear and anxiety forever?
It is not for me to say.
I will only say that there are those who quietly accept this fate.
And there are those who do not.
It is not a question of willpower or determination.
Nor is it a question of what is right or what is good.
It is simply a matter of looking at the issue square in the face, and seeing what arises within one’s interiority.

It would not be wise to condemn the self.
For where is the wisdom in condemning something that does not exist?
Nor would it be wise to attempt to convince oneself that the self does not exist.
For where is the wisdom in introducing yet another self-conflict?

Does the self truly exist?
It does not exist. But this is of little importance.
For any such claim would fly in the face of one’s own perceived experiences.
It would go against all that a human has been told and has lived with for his entire life.
A human has made a home within this self. He has created a life for himself within its walls.
What does it matter to him if it exists or not, if somehow he has wished it into existence?

Through the eyes of a self, life is up one moment and down the very next.
This is verifiable by every living human being.
Why is this the case?
Because the self is an ocean of likes and dislikes.
Would it seem realistic that its encounters would be limited to only the things that it “liked?”
The laws of probability alone would make this an impossibility.
The self bumps into walls throughout the entire span of its existence.
A kind word and the self becomes happy.
A harsh word and the self becomes upset.
The self lives in a world of light and dark shadows.
As it goes, so the human goes.

If there were no self, everything in a human’s life would be . . . Perfect.
But this, for most, would be a little too much to bear.
Namaste.

Jorge Luis Borges is one of the most influential writers, but what made him unique was not that he had original philosophical ideas, but that he used, even appropriated them into his fiction and interpreted them in a new way. Borges famously confessed in an interview that "[But] I wonder if they are my ideas. **Because really I am not a thinker. I have used the philosophers’ ideas for my own private literary purposes,** but I don’t think that I’m a thinker. **==I suppose that my thinking has been done for me by Berkeley, by Hume, by Schopenhauer, by Mauthner perhaps==.**" The interviewer presses Borges by asking whether his work is a search for a system to which Borges replies "No, I wouldn't be as ambitious as all that. I would call it, well, **not science fiction, but rather the fiction of philosophy, or the fiction of dreams–...**"
In this way, it helps to think that your [[writing is about clearing the path for others]].
One way to [[follow your curiosity with a compost heap]] so that you can document ideas that draw their attention to interpret them in new ways.

blocks.page-name: writing is about sharing your darlings

children.content: When you write, it helps to [[write for an ideal reader]]. Thinking how someone will react can spark your sense of wonder give you that much needed boost to write your story. So think of the lines as coded message to a special someone. Imagine how alive they will feel by reading your clandestine letters, make your metaphors uniquely bewitching, along with your language, so that special someone might be transfigured. Make your novel full of darlings so that every line can blossom into its most truthful, living version of itself.
This is not to be confused with [[editing is writing by omission]].

Kwon, R. O. (2021, April 5). A case against killing your darlings: Don't write alone. Catapult. Retrieved May 1, 2022, from https://catapult.co/dont-write-alone/stories/ro-kwon-craft-writing-essay-a-case-against-killing-your-darlings #[[R.O. Kwon]]

I once paid for sex. It was a couple of months after a serious breakup, not like a month or two after, but like five months after. I hadn’t had sex in a long time, and I was very depressed. People think depression is feeling sad for yourself and being gloomy, but depression is projecting anger inwards, and so depression can be very violent. For me it was more like a pendulum. It would oscillate between feelings of euphoria that would be provoked by these wild fantasies of revenge, and then it would all fall down like an anvil of despair and hopelessness at realizing just how much of my life was outside my control. I paid for sex because I thought sex would be the great equalizer. I prayed, I self-medicated, I sought therapy, I reached out, and yet none of these felt like they were relieving the pain inside me. It felt like I had a parasite inside me, and I needed to annihilate it or it would annihilate me. Sex became the chosen method, the exorcism, and it worked. I won’t get into the details about what happened that night. I just felt it was something that needed to be done. She was attractive, and she seemed to like me because she offered half of what she was charging if I wanted to meet with her again. I never did. I never felt compelled to. I moved on, but I never told anyone until much much later. It wasn’t like I started seeing people after that either, but I felt that I was able to channel that energy towards something and I was able to come at peace with the heart ache that I’d been living up to that moment.

To practice honesty in your writing, choose one of the following moments and write a few paragraphs in your journal about it. As you write, pay attention to your inner register about what you’re writing, noting the particular things that make you uneasy. Try to be a little “more honest than you’re comfortable with.” Remember that being brave doesn’t mean you’re not scared; it means you do it anyway. 
• A time when you were deeply embarrassed. • When you regret something you did. • The saddest moment of your life. • A secret you are afraid to talk about. 
Take the work you wrote above and either read it aloud to someone you trust, or read it alone and pretend that you have an audience. Listen to the way you sound and pay attention to the sensations in your body as you’re reading the difficult moment. Consider what you’re afraid of being judged for, or afraid of saying out loud. 
Write those things down.

blocks.page-name: insanity means presenting yourself as unsafe

children.content:
Insanity means presenting yourself as unsafe. That means not concealing your thoughts from others. Sanity is something we learn by concealing our thoughts. In this sense, santiy is an act. It is a performance and one that consume massive levels of energy to sustain. Instead, we should free up this energy to be our true selves. As Johnstone says, "If William Shakespeare had been worried about establishing his sanity, he could never have written Hamlet, let alone Titus Andronicus; Harpo couldn’t have inflated a rubber glove and milked it into the coffee cups; 1 Groucho would never have threatened to horsewhip someone—if he had a horse; W. C. Fields would never have leapt out of the aeroplane after his whisky bottle; Stan Laurel would never have snapped his fingers and ignited his thumb."
When you encounter your finitude, you can begin to let go of the appearance and live more meaningfully. As Shakespeare said, "[[we are such stuff -- as dreams are made on]]".
Johnstone, K. (1989). Impro: Improvisation and the theatre. Methuen Drama. #[[Keith Johnstone]]

blocks.page-name: Heidegger paved the way for existentialism

children.content: Phenomenology is a philosophy, and often seen as the precursor to existentialism, that emphasized on the experience, rather than the interpretation of things. Instead of asking if something is real, focus on what is before you and describe it as closely as possible. Martin Heidegger took it one step further by focusing on the question of Being. What does it mean to be? What are you saying when you say you are? This paved the way for existentialism.
Bakewell, Sarah. At the Existentialist Café: Freedom, Being, and Apricot Cocktails. , 2016. Print. #[[Sarah Bakewell]]

blocks.page-name: an act marks an irreversible change in the story

children.content: Stories usually consist of three acts or three irreversible changes. The first is the opening act which normally consists of 25 percent of the telling. Then the second act which tends to take up the bulk of the story and finally the closing act. The final is the shortest of all, swiftly rising to its climax. These major reversals are carried through escalation and is what gives shape and form to a story.
McKee, Robert. Story: Substance, Structure, Style and the Principles of Screenwriting. , 1997. #[[Robert McKee]]

blocks.page-name: inciting incident forms an expectation of what the story is about

children.content: The inciting incident is an event that knocks the character's life out of balance. By knocking the life out of balance, this event creates pressure for the characters, and this pressure is what enables the reader to form an expectation about what the story is going to be about. This is what is known as the "dramatic question" and is used to create suspense when it merges with empathy for the character. McKee describes this event as turning the neutral charge (balance) sharply positive or negative which in turn puts pressure for the character to act.
McKee, Robert. Story: Substance, Structure, Style and the Principles of Screenwriting. , 1997. #[[Robert McKee]]

Franz Kafka was a consummate introvert. He had many interests, including gardening and reading Platonic dialogues with friends. * Tony vivía con Nani y con Father en el apartamento de Condado y a veces Tony le entraba sus brotes esquizofrénicos y se ponía violento, tanto que tenían que llamar al hospital donde lo sedaban y se lo llevaban con chaleco de fuerza (esa es la historia que a mi me han relatado, pero no se si es cierto). 
* Un hijo esquizofrénico, otro revolucionario arrestado y la otra ideóloga casada con un ideólogo. No creo que habrá sido fácil para mi abuelo, que era estrictamente católico y bien religioso. Nani y Father adoraban al Papa Juan Pablo II, y tenían un cuadro enorme en su casa. Creo que hasta tenían la bendición del Papa. 
* Por otro lado estaba mi padre, Joe Sampson, que al ser el mayor era el que no tenía ningún interés en la revolución, pero si se caso con una mujer bohemia de Ponce de la familia Sacarello que yo la conozco como Tati. Tara, mi hermana mayor, nació en Ponce, luego esta Cathy o Catherine que entiendo yo nació en Syracuse, Nueva York, cuando mi padre estaba haciendo su MBA ahí. Mi padre consiguió el MBA entiendo por ayuda de Fomento, que tenía incentivos para que los puertorriqueños estudiaran en el extranjero para formarse y traer ese conocimiento de vuelta a PR. Luego nació Joey, que es el menor. Mi padre consiguió trabajo con una empresa francesa que vendía textiles, y ahora no me acuerdo el nombre de la empresa francesa pero su jefe era un francés que se llama Pierre (muy original) y su esposa Francinee. Ellos tenían una casa en Aguadilla y tengo muchos recuerdos de esa casa. Yo me acuerdo que íbamos en el volvo de papa que se estaba cayendo en cantos, pero papa era tan terco que no lo cambiaba por nada. Me acuerdo que la tela del techo se caía, una vez había una parte del asiento de pasajero que se había salido del coche, y no se ese carro siempre tenía problemas. Ese carro creo que paso más tiempo en el mecánico que en casa. Y el mecánico era un prieto que se llama Gomez, y tenía un taller en Santuce por barrio obrero y siempre estábamos ahí. 
* En esa casa de Aguadilla Pierre inventaba cosas, era un innovador, y yo me acuerdo que yo me entretenía con lo que había, una vez lleve una máquina que se llama “Creepy Crawlers” y era como un betty crocker pero para niños, dónde podía cocinar chuches de arañas y lagartijos y luego me los comía. 
* Pero nada, volviendo, Papa entonces vendía textiles para esta compañía y se pasaba mucho tiempo viajando por Sudamerica. El vivió un tiempo en Panama y viajaba a Brazil, y otros países. El también llego a vivir un tiempo en Caracas, Venezuela, en los años 70 que todo el mundo dice que esa época eran los “good times”. Ahí el vivía con Tara, Cathy, y Joey y Tati. Papa tiene una anécdota que el les quería regalar un perro y fue a un Pet Shop para conseguir el perro y parece que al día siguiente se había desaparecido y que luego se dio cuenta que el perro estaba entrenado para escaparse y volver a la tienda, donde lo vendían de nuevo, y los de la tienda tenían un guiso montado. No se si es cierto o no. 
* Parece que a Tati no le gustaba Venezuela y ella se quería mudar y entonces ahí parece que se complico la situación. Ella se separo de Papa y se quiso llevar a los niños. En el divorcio ella pidió la custodia de los tres niños y el juez se lo dio pero Cathy y Tara no querían estar con su padre. Tati se mudo a California y Cathy, Tara, y Joey vivían con ella creo que en San Diego o en Los Angeles. Cathy y Tara lo odiaron y volvieron con su padre. Joey se quiso quedar con su madre y entonces el vivía entre Puerto Rico y Los Angeles. 
* La historia de Joey no me la se muy bien y todo lo que se me lo se por Joey, que a veces no es la fuente más fidedigna, pero a mi entender, Joey creo que fue abusado físicamente, entiendo que por uno en particular, y también Joey le enrolaba porros a Tati y pues parece que estaba expuesto al consumo de drogas a una edad muy temprana en su vida. 
* Pero entre todo eso, Joey venía mucho a Puerto Rico. Y aquí empieza la historia de mi madre. 
* Mi madre antes estaba casada con Steve Lausell, y el padre de Steve Lausell lo conocemos como Don Demi, creo que su nombre es Demetorio (un nombre super antiguo como Faustino), y Don Demi era un ingeniero que tenía la fábrica Lausell, que hacían muebles y ventanas y tuvo mucho existo, también se metió en los supermercados y era uno de los socios del supermercado Amigo. Don Demi se caso con una americana que me avergüenza porque no me acuerdo el nombre, pero ella era muy bohemia y la familia de ella eran unos hippies. Un año me regalaron un juego de mesa que se llamaba “Save the Whales” y el punto del juego de mesa era salvar las ballenas, la ficha del juego era un percebe (barnacle) y los obstáculos en el juego eran como “oh no, an oil spill”. 
* Mi madre y Steve era como un geek couple. Mi madre nació en Santurce en la calle colón y mis abuelos se mudaron a Cupey a un suburbio que ahora se me olvida (Venus Gardens?), ella amaba Santurce y odiaba Cupey. San Antonio era de monjas, y tenía que ir en faldas largas, y siempre hablaba de las canciones que cantaban las monjas con guitarra en la guagua y también el abuso de las monjas con la regla, el mantener una distancia en los bailes entre chicos y chicas, y el alarido sonido de las uñas contra la pizarra de tiza cuando no prestaban atención. 
* Mi madre se graduó como a los 15 años porque era una brain, y se fue a estudiar a Catholic University en Washington D.C. pero no le gusto para nada y creo que al mes se fue a la Universidad de Cornell para estudiar biología. Su hermana, mi tía, que la conozco como titi Maquí, estudio en Catholic y se caso con un americano, este si que es un super brain, que se llama Greg que estudio matemáticas y luego consiguió un super trabajo en Intel donde fabrican chips de silicona. Siempre me acuerdo de los bunny suits que son los trajes que tienen que usar y que representa los estándares estrictos que tienen que seguir para fabricar esos chips. 
* Mi madre en aquel entonces salía con Steve, y Steve también estudiaba matemáticas pero en MIT. Luego Steve se graduó de MIT y se metió en derechos (no sé si en la Inter o si en la UPR). Luego de eso el se hizo abogado y empezó su propio bufete, el se especializa en derecho marítimo y tiene que ver con toda la mercancía que entra a Puerto Rico (que es todo, btw). Luego también cuando se consolido los supermercados Amigo el lo siguió con los supermercados SuperMax, que son todos en PR (btw). Obviamente es una persona de mucho poder e influencia. 
* Mi madre se graduó de Cornell y luego empezó en la escuela de medicina de Puerto Rico. Steve era mayor y ya estaba ejerciendo abogacía. Luego más tarde tuvieron a Steven, mi madre dice que el parto duro 20 horas o algo así, una barbaridad, y luego Steve padre le pego cuernos a mi madre entiendo que con la secretaria. Mi madre se enteró y formo la pendeja creo que en el medio de un servicarro de Burger King, algo así. Lo mando a la mierda. 
* Steve padre era alcohólico y luego del divorcio toco fondo. Como tenían a Steven pues mantuvieron una amistad y compartían custodia. Steve le presentaba a todas las mujeres que estaba saliendo y mi madre casi nunca aprobaba de ninguna hasta que conoció a Daisy, que al día de hoy es su esposa, y tienen dos nenes y una nena. Adrian que es el mayor y estudio ingeniera y es un poco complicado, Cristian, que estudio cine en NYU y quiere ser director, y la menor que es de la edad de Carolina (la hija de Tara) y es una geek en el sentido bueno, tiene una voz espectacular y esta metido como en 400 actividades y estudia en Maria Reina. Los otros estudiaron en San Ignacio. 
* Entre Steven (mi hermano) y yo, siempre nos burlamos de San Ignacio como un “boys club” que se creen la gran mierda porque tienen un anillo que solo sirve para besarse el culo. 
* Yo a Steve padre siempre lo conocí como tío. Y al día de hoy no creo que me hayan sentado a explicarme quien realmente es tu “tío Steve.” Pero yo me quedaba con ellos cuando mis padres salían juntos. 
* Digo todo esto para volver a Joey. Joey cuando venía a Puerto Rico trabajaba con Steve. Hacía cosas como transportar documentos y hacer diligencias para Steve. La cosa es que Joey no tenía licencia de conducir y le prestaban el carro. cuando mi madre se entero se enfado y al día de hoy s algo que siguen hablando. 
* Joey también chingaba con la secretaria de Steve, creo y no creo que tenía ni quince años (no se si es cierto o no). 
* De niño, me acuerdo que pasaba veranos y tiempo con Joey y el y Che siempre eran muy buenos conmigo. Joey me llevaba a conseguir helado, siempre me acuerdo que el me viraba al revés, y ponía mies pies en el techo y empezaba a caminar por el techo de la casa. 
* Steve también era muy bueno conmigo. Ellos tienen una casa en Dorado en Breñas y tenían una hamaca ahí, y el usaba la hamaca y yo me encerraba como un capullo y le daba vueltas enteras a la hamaca, chocaba con el techo de la terraza y luego daba una vuelta al otro lado y iba volando. También me tiraba al aire y todo el mundo siempre se cagaba porque realmente volaba, pero a el no le importaba. 
* Papa también obviamente. 
* Steve padre luego de haber pegado cuernos a mi madre metió en la religion episcopal o luterana, donde las misas duraban como 6 horas y llevaba a Steven y Steven se moría del aburrimiento. 
* Luego Steve padre se convirtió en pastor. Regalaba mucho dinero a los deambulantes y Joey creo que aprendió mucho de esto, y ahora Steve le da muchísimo dinero a la iglesia y a los menos afortunados. 
* Ahora me toca hablar de mis abuelos de parte madre, a Antonia Corona nacida en un pueblo rural en Italia, Campobasso en Molise (que los italianos conocen como “Mole-isnt” porque no conocen a nadie ese sitio) y mi Abuelo Jose Antonio Recurt, que viene del pueblo de Humacao.

Method actors often build characters by drawing emotions from lived experience. Robert De Niro shaved his teeth for "Cape Fear" whereas Leonardo DiCaprio prepared for his role for "The Revenant" by eating raw bison. But you don't need to mine experiences from your own life to build a character. Another way to build characters is by removing or anything that is not the character. This is what Jeremy Strong from 'Succession' calls "identity diffusion" and sees it as a "more complete vessel for the work at hand".
Identity diffusion is similar to editing in that [[editing is writing by omission]].

Schulman, M. (2021, December 3). On "succession," jeremy strong doesn't get the joke. The New Yorker. Retrieved April 30, 2022, from https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2021/12/13/on-succession-jeremy-strong-doesnt-get-the-joke (1) #[[New Yorker]]

blocks.page-name: setbacks help escalate a story's conflict

children.content: A setback enables further escalation in the story's conflict because the character's fear of losing his [[object of desire]] will amplify. A setback serves the purpose of pushing the character deeper into a crisis. The setback caused by the character's reaction will give way to an insight that will make the character re-evaluate his values. The purpose of the insight is to make the character aware that he will have to take an even riskier course of action in hopes that it will deliver what he truly wants.
Mckee, Robert, and Tom Gerace. Storynomics: Story-Driven Marketing in the Post-Advertising World. Illustrated, Twelve, 2018. #[[Robert McKee]]

Habits are not difficult to change, they are difficult to identify because we are often unaware of the cues that trigger them. To change or replace habits, you first need to identify the cues that trigger the habit. That is because once triggered, a routine takes place in pursuit of a reward. Keeping track of the cues that trigger habits can pave the way for building healthier habits over time.
Duhigg, Charles. The Power of Habit : Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business. New York, N.Y. :Random House : Books on Tape, 2012. #[[Charles Duhigg]]

blocks.page-name: desire is not the same thing as motivation

children.content: Desire and motivation are different things. Desire informs us *what* the character wants and longs for. Motivation, on the other hand, tells us *why* the character desires something. You can [[pay attention to desire to understand the story]] by asking "what" questions like "what is something this character wants but does not have? Then you can use "why" questions to understand their motivation, like "why does this character yearn for this?"
McKee, Robert. Story: Substance, Structure, Style and the Principles of Screenwriting. , 1997. #[[Robert McKee]]

5. Active voice > passive voice (more like natural conversation)

blocks.page-name: tech optimism exploits human yearning and desire

children.content: Technological optimism is the belief that innovation and technology will cure society's problems. This idea that all problems–economic inequality, chronic unemployment, drug addiction, crime, rural decay, inflation, low fertility rates, isolation, depression, climate change– are scientific and technological problems and therefore require technological and scientific solutions helps drive technological optimism. In this sense, nationalism and technological optimism are similar in that both belief systems exploit human yearning and desire by promising stability and control over our futures. Wang argues tech companies are well aware of this, going so far as to use technology to create narratives that "promise frictionless prediction and control, and optimize to deliver happiness forever."

blocks.page-name: verbal containers allow the emergence of certain ideas

children.content: Words are containers for ideas, which ultimately shape and determine the way we think about a certain topic. In her defense of fiction, Zadie Smith points to the politicization of "cultural appropriation". She writes, "we treat those two carefully chosen words as if they were elemental, neutral in themselves, handed down from the heavens. When of course they are only, like all language, a verbal container, which, like all such containers, allows the emergence of certain ideas while limiting the possibilities of others." She goes on to say, "what would our debates about fiction look like, I sometimes wonder, if our preferred verbal container for the phenomenon of writing about others was not "cultural appropriation" but rather "interpersonal voyeurism" or "profound-other-fascination" or even "cross-epidermal reanimation"? Smith goes on to conclude that these discussions would still be vibrant (and even furious) but they would not be the same. "Aren't we a little too passive in the face of inherited concepts? We allow them to think for us, and to stand as place markers when we can't be bothered to think."
Ultimately, labels shape our thinking. In fact, broadening the conversation could help us overcome [[all the problems in the world are caused by miscommunication]].
It helps to understand that [[language is a musical instrument for ideas]], and that words are not static but fluid and capable of change.

Otro tema de hoy: ayer estábamos hablando en casa y Leri hizo una anécdota interesante.

El matón de Trujillo (el dictador de República Dominicana) tenia un apodo que ahora no me acuerdo, pero su nombre era Anselmo Paulino. El fue el autor del asesinato de las hermanas merabilas (espero que asi se escriba).

Pues Tito, mi abuelo era de Humacao. Pero parece que su mama acogía nenes para matricularlos en la Central (no se si es la central la escuela en santurce o la central, la central de refinar azúcar, puede que sea la de refinar azúcar, que tenían un sitio para los nenes donde los padres trabajaban). Entonces, Tito desde muy joven tenia un amigo que se llama Saqui. Y Eran muy amigos.

Saqui era de la República Dominicana y conocía a Anselmo desde muy joven. Parece que cuando llega Trujillo, Anselmio lo envían a ser viajes a Puerto Rico porque ahí es donde depositaban el dinero, probablemente de actividades ilegales.

Me parece que a Saqui lo amenazaban con decir que tienes que recibir a Anselmio y tratarlo bien y muchas otras cosas. Y parece que Tito, mi abuelo, como tenia coche, parece que era el que llevaba a Anselmio al banco para depositar el dinero y lo tenia que acompañar.
Me dicen que se parece a Jabba the Hut, que era bien gordo.

Y parece que un dia en el banco, acompañado con Tito, alguien le empieza a gritar, "Anselmio, asesino! Te voy a matar!!" Y Anselmio le decía, "pues mátame! Aquí estoy, mátame!" Y Tito parece que al lado rezando a Dios que nada le pasara.

Parece que Anselmio como tenía mucho dinero pues daba regalos, y a mama le regalo un reloj de esos redondos pero ella no sabia nada de quien era o que hacia, pues habrá tenido com 7 años en aquel entonces.
Interesante anécdota. Anselmio, te voy a matar! Mátame, mátame.

blocks.page-name: plato's cave is about the value of pursuing an examined life

children.content: Plato's cave is a metaphor for what a philosopher is. In Book VII of Plato's Republic, the reader is presented with a parable of the cave, illustrating the escape of mankind from the world of illusion to the freedom and radiance of the world of reality. The story is presented in order to show the reader that what we think of as reality might just be an illusion and true freedom lies in the ability to recognize this. Plato's Cave teaches us not to take reality at face value since reality is infinitely more complex than the eye can see. The Matrix is based of this idea, while also combining different ideas for techno-libertarianism and psychedelic drug use. Plato's Cave reminds us that most of us have a default to reality at face value, but that underneath there is another more vivid world, one of ideas. Here's a video [Orson Welle's explaining Plato's Cave](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QFi8JUIwu2s&feature=youtu.be) It is the task of the enlightened to ascend to learning and to see the good but to be willing to descend again to those prisoners and to share their troubles and their honors whether they are worth having or not and they must do even with the prospect of death. They shall give of their help to one another whether each class will help the community.

blocks.page-name: how Americans got hooked on toothpaste

children.content: > It might surprise you to learn that in early 20th America, hardly anyone brushed their teeth; in fact, so many recruits during World War I had rotting teeth that government officials declared poor dental hygiene a national security risk. That all changed, however, when a marketing genius by the name of Claude Hopkins was convinced by an old friend to apply his skills to hawking toothpaste. Claude was the man responsible for taking unknown products like Goodyear and Quaker Oats and turning them into household names. His signature tactic was to tap into the habit loop by anchoring the product to a specific trigger, regardless of how preposterous the connection. Quaker Oats, for example, owes its success to Claude being able to convince America that it provided 24-hour energy – but only if you ate a bowl every morning. Claude chose a similar cue to turn toothpaste into a national habit. His ads read, “Just run your tongue across your teeth. You’ll feel a film – that’s what makes your teeth look ‘off color’ and invites decay.” After giving people the cue, he continued with images of beautiful white smiles and the statement, “Note how many pretty teeth are seen everywhere. Millions are using a new method of teeth cleaning. Why should any woman have dingy film on her teeth? Pepsodent removes the film!” The claim was downright false; the “film” is a naturally occurring membrane, and toothpaste doesn’t do anything to remove it. However, the cue was universal and easily apparent, and people bought the connection to the reward (beautiful teeth). Within a decade, toothpaste usage had expanded from 7% of the population to 65%.
This is why Duhigg says [[habits are difficult to identify]].
Duhigg, Charles. The Power of Habit : Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business. New York, N.Y. :Random House : Books on Tape, 2012. #[[Charles Duhigg]]

blocks.page-name: exposition is the function of monologue

children.content: In a story, a character is always addressing someone. In a monologue, the character is addressing the reader either directly or indirectly by engaging in an self-to-self internal dialogue. The purpose of a monologue is to keep the reader up-to-date and to help give exposition on events that might happen later on in the story. The monologue is another way to give access to the consciousness of the character, and how [[the illusion of intimacy makes fictional characters believable]]. When writing a monologue, it helps to remember that every word spoken to the reader or to the character needs to satisfy a purpose.
McKee, Robert. Dialogue: The Art of Verbal Action for Page, Stage, and Screen. Later Printing, Twelve, 2016. #[[Robert McKee]]

A wounded deer - leaps highest 
I've heard the hunter tell; 
'Tis but the ecstasy of death, 
And then the brake is still. 
The smitten rock that gushes, 
The trampled steel that springs: 
A cheek is always redder 
Just where the hectic stings! 
Mirth is mall of anguish, 
In which its cautious arm 
Lest anybody spy the blood 
And, "you're hurt" exclaim

Pain and suffering reveals our humanity, so the more we share our pain or our story, the more we will soar and the better our story will be. [[Emily Dickinson]] 's poem "a wounded deer leaps highest" captures this sentiment:

blocks.page-name: get a reaction from your reader

children.content:
One day, serving as a note taker on a conference call at the environmental engineering company where I was working, I started, out of boredom, writing these dark little Seussian poems. When I finished one, I’d draw a cartoon to go along with it. By the end of the call, I had around ten of these poem-and-cartoon pairs, and because they weren’t my “real” writing, I almost threw them out as I left work that day. But something stopped me. I brought them home, dropped them on the table, went off to see the kids. And then I heard, from back at the table, the sound of genuine laughter, from my wife, as she read those stupid little poems.
This was, I realized with a start, the first time in years that anyone had reacted to my writing with pleasure.

One of the greatest pleasures of writing is to have someone react to your story with delight. George Saunders writes that what gave him a direction in writing was hearing his wife laugh at jokes he had scribbled down while bored and taking notes on a call.
Reminds me of **Ideal Reader** from Stephen King. [[write for an ideal reader]]
Saunders, G. (2022). A swim in a pond in the rain: In which Four Russians give a master class on writing, reading, and life. Bloomsbury Publishing. #[[George Saunders]]

Full quote: In this book, I’ve made the case for embracing the truth about your limited time and limited control over that time—not simply because it’s the truth, so you might as well face it, but because it’s actively empowering to do so. By stepping more fully into reality as it actually is, you get to accomplish more of what matters, and feel more fulfilled about it
1. Adopt a “fixed volume” approach to productivity]]
Any strategy for limiting your work in progress will help here (here), but perhaps the simplest is to keep two to-do lists, one “open” and one “closed.” The open list is for everything that’s on your plate and will doubtless be nightmarishly long. Fortunately, it’s not your job to tackle it: instead, feed tasks from the open list to the closed one—that is, a list with a fixed number of entries, ten at most. The rule is that you can’t add a new task until one’s completed. (You may also require a third list, for tasks that are “on hold” until someone else gets back to you.)
instead, train yourself to get incrementally better at tolerating that anxiety, by consciously postponing everything you possibly can, except for one thing. Soon, the satisfaction of completing important projects will make the anxiety seem worthwhile—and since you’ll be finishing more and more of them, you’ll have less to feel anxious about anyway
But even in these essential domains, there’s scope to fail on a cyclical basis: to aim to do the bare minimum at work for the next two months, for example, while you focus on your children, or let your fitness goals temporarily lapse while you apply yourself to election canvassing

Separate your to dos with an "open" and "closed" list of tasks. Your open list should contain all the things you want to do at some point in the future. Your closed list on the other hand, are the actual things you will focus.The idea of an "open" and "closed list is what Burkeman defines as "adopting a 'fixed volume' approach to productivity". The aim is that you can't add a new task until one of the task in the closed list is completed. This will help you from feeling overwhelmed by the things you want to do.
Burkeman, O. (2021). Four Thousand Weeks: Time Management for mortals. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. #[[Oliver Burkeman]]

blocks.page-name: build characters through empathy not sympathy

children.content: An empathetic character means being able to understand and identify where their feelings and emotions come from, even though you don't agree with them. Sympathetic characters, on the other hand, are characters you find likable. You can make a character do things you find repulsive, but if you are able to see and understand why he or she would behave in such a way, then your story will be much more compelling. This is because empathetic characters result in what McKee calls a "mirror experience." The reader identifies with the character by recognizing a shared humanity. This identification results in a "subconscious switch", whereby the reader now identifying with the story is able to see the story through the character's eyes. In doing so, the reader replaces the storified desire for his or her real-life desire, making the story much more powerful.
McKee, Robert. Story: Substance, Structure, Style and the Principles of Screenwriting. , 1997. #[[Robert McKee]]
