blocks.page-name: Adam and Eve is a metaphor for human's proclivity for evil

children.content:
The snake in the garden of Adam and Evil represents the devil, but it is also a metaphor for human's proclivity for evil. We have seen the enemy, and the enemy is us. The story of Adam and Eve shows that the first woman made the first man self-conscious and resentful. The first man blames the woman, and later blamed God. This is part of the human condition.
> In any case, the serpent tells Eve that if she eats the forbidden fruit, she won’t die. Instead, her eyes will be opened. She will become like God, knowing good from evil. Of course, the serpent doesn’t let her know she will be like God in only that one way. But he is a serpent, after all. Being human, and wanting to know more, Eve decides to eat the fruit. Poof! She wakes up: she’s conscious, or perhaps self-conscious, for the first time. (edited) The snake inhabits each of our souls. This is the reason, as far as I can tell, for the strange Christian insistence, made most explicit by John Milton, that the snake in the Garden of Eden was also Satan, the Spirit of Evil itself. The importance of this symbolic identification—its staggering brilliance—can hardly be overstated. The story of Adam and Eve shows that the first woman made the first man self-conscious and resentful. The first man blames the woman, and later blamed God. This is part of the human condition. This is exactly how every spurned male feels, to this day. First, he feels small, in front of the potential object of his love, after she denigrates his reproductive suitability. Then he curses God for making her so bitchy, himself so useless (if he has any sense) and Being itself so deeply flawed. Then he turns to thoughts of revenge. How thoroughly contemptible (and how utterly understandable). At least the woman had the serpent to blame, and it later turns out that snake is Satan himself, unlikely as that seems. (edited)
Peterson, Jordan. 12 Rules for Life: An Antidote to Chaos. Penguin, 2019. #[[Jordan Peterson]]

The only reason she chose me because I was a PR 33 year old who is manager of Tottenham and saw me as a model for the future of the Democratic Party. I think I might be playing too much fantasy PL - a while back
*   November 14th, 2020   #  Dreams-Nightmares   Anoche soñé que yo tenía una aventura sexual con Saskia pero bien bien bien intensa. Estabamos follando como animales y no se como pero creo que nuestros padres nos habían encontrado y luego mis padres se hicieron amigo a sus padres. Fue bien raro, pero también estaba Juancho y había como algo de voyeurismo ahí. Fue bien heavy. Y Saskia confesó que quería follar conmigo desde hace mucho tiempo.
Jueves 17 de agosto 11:58 pm.

Hoy es jueves, estoy acostado en la cama. Hoy hubo un ataque terrorista en la Ramblas. Estaba resacado hoy porque anoche estuve en las fiestas de Gracia, Yonah tuvo un pica pica en su piso y estuvimos ahí. Anoche antes de irme me despedí de Neus, y estuve con Mimi que estaba bien borracha, con Marc, Daniel, Saskia, Gemma, Duncan, Juan, Lisa, y varias personas mas.

Yo salí alrededor de la 1:30 del piso, resacado, ayer me acoste como a las 4 de la mañana. Salí afuera y lo primero que pensé fue que el dia estaba hermoso. Hacia sol y no habían muchas nubes, a diferencia de ayer que hacia un poco de frío y estaba nublado y por eso no fui a la playa. Fui a Pim Pam, comi en el piso y luego llego Marta que vino a limpiar.

Ya eran como las 5, que habrá sido cuando fue el ataque. Pero en ese momento yo baje N9 salon para ir a recortarme el pelo. La mujer, que se parece muchísimo a Florence de Florence and the machine, me dijo que regresara a las 6:30. Eran las cinco así que no sabia que hacer y me fui hacia Arc de Triomf a sentarme y leer un rato. Ahí fue que recibo un mensaje de Duncan en el grupo diciendo que parece que hubo un ataque, que una furgoneta se metió en las Ramblas a tropellar personas.

Rouli hizo un comentario de que si era gente odiando a los turistas. Como no se sabía nada no parecía tan serio. Yo tampoco lo tome tan en serio al principio porque dijeron al principio que solo habían heridos. Que no había muerto gente. Y eso pues me hizo a mi pensar que no lo debería de tomar tan en serio pero estaba alarmado y un poco preocupado. Ahí decido regresar al piso y cuando entro esta Lucas viendo a la vanguardia en vivo y esta Marta limpiando el piso.

Ahí cuando empecé a ver las imágenes fue que me di cuenta que era más grave. Le envié un mensaje a mis padres para dejarle saber que estaba bien, pero aún ahí no sabían si habían muertos y no sabia si la noticia iba a pasar más allá de Barcelona.
Luego escucho que han muerto gente y ahí creo que sentí un poco débil en el estómago y en las piernas.
No sabia si los locales iban a estar cerrado en el Born por cuál decido llamar a la perruqueria y me dicen que están abiertos y que no van a cerrar porque no están dentro de la zona afectada.

Bajo y entro y pues el que me atiende es un joven que tiene la mitad del pelo rojo y la otra mitad azul, para romper el hielo empezamos a hablar de lo que esta sucediendo. Me dice que ha visto lo de la vanguardia pero que le han enviado vídeos del incidente y que es muy gráfico. Un día raro para irse a recortar. Yo con mis incertidumbres de mi imagen y mi pelo y como me veo en medio de todo este lío. Pero así es. Florence esta al lado recortando a otro tío y ella hablando casualmente bochincheando de otras cosas como si nada ha pasado. Pero ahí queda. El de recorte me pasa la peinilla con maquina de secar y pasa un poco de arcilla para aguantar el pelo. Me despido y subo al piso a ver que está pasando.

Ahora son las 12:14 y las ultimas seis horas han sido un poco surreal. Las fiestas de Gracia se cancelaron, aquí en el Born los restaurantes han cerrado menos el mosquito y algunos sitios. Se escucha un helicóptero y ambulancias pasar.
Orita salí con Lucas y caminamos un rato a ver si había algo pero estaba todo sombrío aunque había gente afuera bebiendo y hablando.

Vi algunas de las imágenes y me parece que va ser más de 13 fallecidos, si vas de plaza Cataluña al mosaico de Miro hay un cojonañ de gente. Es una locura. Nunca en mi vida he estado tan cerca a un ataque, pero estoy bien no siento nada, es el ambiente. No me puedo imaginar esa escena. El caos la confusión.
La cosa con todo esto es que no sabes nada de lo que está pasando y el miedo o lo que sea te hace especular.
Un libro de dejar de beber era lo que me estaba leyendo.
Día 6
It's 7:52 am I just took a shower and I'm sitting on the comforter, I have a message from Ariana but I'm ignoring it for now. Focusing on me.
Things I was thinking about late last night before passing out..

a) I am the water from the jungle. I felt an energy that wanted to explode the room I felt so much positive force and good vibes that I felt it was going to bust open from my chest. This is what Puerto Rico has given me, so much energy so much belief that I'm ready to share.
b) I want us as a group to have wonderful experiences together. I want to do some ice breakers in the class like blind fold classmates and have them serve us food while blindfolded and things of that nature. Let's get weird, let's get uncomfortable. The obstacle is the way - something I would like to have painted on the wall at the IED.
also that I have to propose the things I want: I want to stay here- I want a Spanish girlfriend. I can definitely do it, just need to propose it and take measurable steps to obtain it.
Also that I have a story. I have an awesome story and that is the story that I want to share with others. From PR to all the crap that happened to mentoring, now being here. All of it.

Yesterday we had planned the design tour at 11 am, I hadn't slept well the night before so I got up at 10:30 am and rushed to the IED when I got there one Spanish guy was using the room and asked if there was class and I said yes assuming that we would be taking the classes there and left me the keys as he left. But then no one showed up and I was getting anxious. Then I saw Mauro and then I got a message from Wendy that they were waiting for us, we didn't know where so we rushed to Carrer de Gran Gracia were the group was waiting for us. We got lost for a bit until a few messages came through and then we found the group. Annie, the tour leader was a bit pissed, she is an older lady from Britain, very bohemian dressed, but very well acquainted with the city, she ended up being a great guide.

It was just me, Mauro, Wendy, Tessa, and Lukas. We first walked into Colmillo de Morsa, which means Walrus Tusk, the fashion designer there was beautiful lady probably around my age or younger who was pregnant, she talked to us about her style, how she works, how fashion is all about deadlines, winter style, summer style etc. I though about what kind of man would she have and then around that time a Asian looking guy, I would say Korean or Japanese not really sure walked in with a guitar, he actually seemed pretty cool. Then she talked to us about two fashion magazines one I can't remember the name and the other which I can remember because it's got the most ridiculous name ever: fucking young. Now, that doesn't sound super hilarious but here a Spanish person say fucking young in English and you'll flip. It takes effort, they need to pause, and of course there's probably some element of guilt of having to say that out loud in front of others for fear of offending anyone. But it does the job, I remember the name and it sticks out.

When we were in Colmillo de Morsa I asked a few questions. Like what does colmillo de Morsa mean and what would you advise people who want to get into your industry? I was super attracted to her, she was beautiful, self assured with her own business and passionate about what she was doing. I really admire that. She talked about how she has two stores one in Gracia where we were at and another in el Borne, which she says has more traffic and because people come from outside are a little bit edgier in their tastes and buy more exotic things. Interesting.

I thought about California Closets. The demand for it being here, if anything. A California Closets in Barna would be amazing. It would be so perfect. I thought about doing my masters thesis on a business proposal like that, interviewing people from different backgrounds to explore the viability of opening up the business here. How would that work?

We left Colmillo de Morsa and walked down not too far and entered now into something completely different. A contemporary art and design gallery. We had to walk down some steps like if entering a club and there was a huge white wall. Annie spoke on the intercom and the door opened. Inside there was a long hall adorned with a metallic arc that we had to walk to get through. The collector was this lightly bearded man with grey hair, a belly, sort of Ernest Hemingway and comfortably dressed, it was unassuming but he spoke in casual relaxed tone. He showed us throughout the gallery, the art they had and then the furniture, I thought this may be a common gallery but he had furniture pieces by Corbusier and later explained by Jean Prouvé, perhaps the most famous furniture designer from 50s in Barcelona. Any chair would be around 30,000 euros upwards. And he said that his clients are small group usually foreigners that come from outside (US, Netherlands, Belgium) who take up the market. He showed us an exclusive piece that only one of in its entirety. Gallery name is Gabriel Miquel Alzueta. He seemed cold and first but then opened up and was quite nice. Everyone here is nice. He said some interesting things too. First, he said that as a collector he aggressively (ok I'm embellishing) avoids the word investment. He believes people should buy art because it makes a valuable addition to the home, something nice to look at, he doesn't believe in the speculative aspect of it. The second thing he said, and this was from one of my questions, is that it doesn't matter what material it is or the quality of the wood in the valuation of it, the history, the person who made it and the craftsmanship are the elements that determines its value. This is interesting because the value is not just one thing, it's a different set of factors combined. I guess the story of it is what creates its value. How well it is told. He also said that the business of furniture art From 50s as gallery had 20 years and that he had been 15 years in the business. He said the first people to get into the market where smart ones. The bought the pieces of furniture at a relatively low cost and then spent a lot of money publishing books and creating awareness of the pieces in universities and galleries. Now the market is too expensive he says. He also talked a lot about Brazil. But said he doesn't like tropical woods, he likes American and European woods more. We walked around took some pictures above which mostly just had abstract art which I thought was crap and then felt guilty for thinking that as I assume this guy probably has a lot of money invested in this and most of what art is thinking what we think it is, it's crap though. We gave thanks and left.
The next place we went too was a small industrial design shop called AOO - Altrescoses, Otrascosas, Other Things. The guy who attended is looked very Catalan, tall, skinny, long straight hair and beastly beard, sort of a flat head and a large crooked nose. There were a lot of interesting pieces, mostly made from wood, chairs, and as the name suggests other things. He talked about his business how he has the store and has very little clients from people who walk in but majority of clients come from architects, restauranters, people from interior design who commission bigger works.
He also talked about VINÇON, a small design shop that closed last year but was very famous in Barcelona.

I asked him if he had a business strategy for finding the b2b customers and people of that nature and he joked around and say no but if he did he wouldn't share it. I laughed. He was very cool very open about his stuff. But didn't really seem to have a solid strategy for running business, seemed to be more on the design side of things. He talked about his work the fact that he has some artisans one from Valencia who makes Rattan chairs, and another knife maker from Mallorca, neither of their children want to take over the business, i sympathize deeply with that, but these are old crafts that preserve their culture and I admire what he isn't doing with that. The visit was brief but nice. We were starting to get hungry in the group. On our way to another shop we passed by the only fascist bookstore in Barcelona. Annie said that the entrance had built in security thick glass (acrylic?) because people had tried to burn down the store a few times. You could see Hitler books, kinda freaky, I felt like walking in the store and asking the guy at the desk what he thought about free speech? 
Then we went to Lydia Delgado store, I would say a bit on the higher end from Colmillo de Morsa, Marc attended us, he is this gay man who reminded me a bit of Antonio Santini because they looked similar and are both gay, but extremely nice guy. Talked to us about the store about what they do, their style is more retro but with vivid colors (shocking pink, mink furs). Then at one point Lydia Delgado walked in but shot up straight to the stairs and murmured hi good day as she rushed up, but politely. He said they sell outside mostly to Japan and that made sense to me because I could see how the Japanese style fits with her, retro, elegant, but also vivid colors. It also reminded me of tres mujeres from Old San Juan. Very nice style, very feminist there was women illustration in Delgado from her herself. She was a ballerina turned fashion designer and has a lot of talent. You can tell she works very hard. She's been in the business for 40'years according to Marc but from what i briefly saw from her she looks like she has 40 years old so it seemed a bit strange to me.

Annie told Marc we would be going to the Loeve next and Marc dropped his jaw in awe. As an expression of I'm so jealous. We left and went to the Loeve which was a bit further apart so in the way Annie stopped us and started giving us some brief history of Barcelona. She said the 3 most famous architects from modernists period is Lluis Domenech I Muntaner, Antoni Gaudi, y Josep Puig I Cadalfach. She showed us a building by Muntaner (I believe) which is a red bricked building by Passieg de Gracia which the roof it just looks like a bunch of cables it's called the Fundacio Antoni Tapes. It has a tubing around to represent a cloud and atop sits a chair which is supposed to be the artist, who sits atop the cloud. Antoni Tapes was the most famous artist after Miro died. 
We were at a building by Passieg that had sand and I can't remember the name now.

Then we made it to Loeve, Loeve looks like a Louie Voutton store, everyone is dressed like European police, very good looking and people all around. You know this is very high end because of the street and the feeling you get. A lady greets us and gives us the history and talks about Loeve as this German who landed in Spain and started making bags, leather art is perfect by Muslim cultures which she size able chunk of Spain for over 800 years. The leather work is beautiful and I thought how much money laundering is probably done here, I also thought how these elegant things like leather and mink fur are nice and while horrible for the animals is degradable. But it feels awfully like a fascist store. A Chinese couple walked in and immediately a clerk showed up and said Ni Hao and started talking to Chinese, I wondered how many people are here and how many languages do they speak. It was amazing she said there was 24 on staff and they spoke basically all the UN languages. She said Loeve also sponsors a lot in the arts, Liceo, apprenticeships with them and also holds the most prestigious award for poetry in Barcelona.

We left said goodbye to Annie and wondered about, then we went with the group had some burgers and talked for a while. I think Tessa is pretty, Wendy is very efficient and also pretty, she showed me some pics of her and her Bf in northern Sweden watching the Borealis.

It's 11:19 pm...
I'm tired, today was great as well. We started off with Annie, she looked the same as yesterday, it's as if she lives in a time vacuum and is on a perpetual tour with the same energy and excitement but it was great.

She took us to artisanal craft center in Call by old Jewish quarters close to Liceo. These were all typical Catalan designs made by local artisans, there were different costumes in the back. Each had its own purpose. There was one from women in villages who would pick up herbs and make medical treatments but were later burned and mirrored bu the inquisition. A lot of history.
Then we went to Hangar Org - sign up for newsletter, a residency for artist in the industrial part of the town / poblenou, real nice. We got a tour of the whole thing, I was not paying much attention and found the tour guide to be a bit slow but she was wearing an interesting hoodie, the arms were like big cut up holes.

Then after that we went to Palo Alto Market and met Javier Mariscal. He was this weird bizarre and goofy guy. He was making jokes I fell for half of them but he showed us a cool video he made about BCN and walked us through it, he is the most famous living illustrator in Spain!! And he was just super casual and talking to us like nothing. He was flirting with Annie, smoking cigarettes, and just hanging around. This was a big deal, it was great.

After that we went back to school and met Jurgen when we began team building classes. We did core My identity is more going to be...
Literature background / decided to jump into design thinking. Yeah, that's it. That's me that's what I want.

I also had a beer today, it's been four weeks without alcohol, eventually it was going to happen. But I'm a great guy and I'm still going to continue everything else I've proposed myself so I'm super down for this year and I want to make the most out of it. Looking forward. Sleepy, tired, still need to do some work but ready to call it a night.

Funny thing is Jordi from the class is super sweet guy and said that foreign girls are easier than locals who are more introverted. I thought about Ariana of course, but to tie in the theme today of storytelling, what do you want, to sleep with Spanish guys and say oh I had a Spanish boyfriend, the Spanish guy will say yeah PuertonRican girls are mad easy, and that's that, of make somethings wonderful and great and have a story we can tell for ages, we lived here, we made our life. It was great.

First night I have a beer in 28 days. 
Thought I want to make myself feel guilty by saying I didn't pray the rosary, but I never really prayed the rosary, it's something that I just recently got into. I'm going to continue doing it because it feels nice but I'm going to continue.
I want to write a short story about Mariscal Studio my experience there and with him. How that story would be- like a Chac mol.
I have a confession to make: I studied literature and now switching careers to design management.

April 14

Hoy ha sido una basura de día, me siento frustrado y no se que puedo hacer. Ariana me tiene un poco loco hoy, no he hablado con Yonah y me gustaría hacer las paces pero quiero ir poco a poco. ¿Qué carajo paso hoy? Pues no tengo idea. No hice absolutamente nada y me hace sentir fatal. Revise dos capítulos de JavaScript pero no creo que he mejorado el pensamiento trabaje un poco la página personal.. 

ok ahora voy a parar y voy hacer lo siguiente
Le voy avisar Ariana esta noche para llamarla y para ver la peli. Voy a escribirle a Yonah. Voy a preparar la cena. Y voy a hacer algo de ejercicios. Y ya está. 

Eso es todo l que tengo que hacer por hoy. 

Mañana, no le voy a prestar un cargo de atención al portfolio porque no se que quiero expresar si no se que puedo hacer. 

Quiero escribir un rato. Mañana voy a quedar con Matt y luego de eso voy a trabajar un poco en las cosas que quiero hacer. 

Grabar mi voz con un artículo. 
Etc. 

REVISION: UPDATE A LAS 9:30 pm

OK… imagínate que hoy acaba la cuarentena 

No logro tomar el momento para sentarme y pensar. Ahora mismo la idea que tengo es escribir una carta de amor a Robi ahora y una carta de desamor ahora. Pero más allá de eso es hacer una breve reflexión sobre como ha ido la cuarentena y imaginarme que hoy acaba. Que ya, después de esto, todo sigue igual, ¿qué haría distinto? ¿qué creo que me hubiese ido mejor? ¿y qué me hubiese gustado hacer? 

Me gusto mucho lo que leí anoche 

Transcript. 

AND SCENE: 

Se acabo la cuarentena, no se que quiero hacer pero estoy en el mismo sitio. Siento que he hecho un montón de cosas esotéricas pero no estoy nada cerca donde me hubiese gustado estar y ahora pues tengo que buscar un trabajo y tengo que encontrar la manera de ganarme la vida y no tengo idea como es que lo voy a lograr. 

Pero como si eso fuese lo único porque ahora Ariana quiere que vayas a visitarla y espera que te quedes con ella un rato y ahora no vas a tener otro remedio más que ir. Entonces se te acabo todo. ¿Qué te hubiese gustado haber hecho distinto? 
	. Creo que una de las cosas que he aprendido es mucho sobre mí, como yo soy como persona, y lo mucho que estoy intentando de hacer cosas 

OK… cambiamos. Me toca entrevistar, qué es algo que te ha gustado hasta ahora en esta cuarentena? Bueno, tengo tiempo para mí, no estoy bebiendo, puedo mantener el ayuno intermitente, no estoy gastando así que está bien, no tengo que bregar con Marc, ni con mierdas de copies, ni nada de ese estilo. He logrado desarrollar mi «segunda mente» con Roam, revisado un montón de libros que tengo pero más importante, extraído su conocimiento y archivarlo para poder utilizarlo en cualquier otra ocasión. He logrado actualizar mis «decks» en Anki, y esto me permite poder revisar vocabulario y reglas de gramática cada día, aunque quiero seguir mejorando y creando nuevos «decks». Por otro lado he estado viendo pelis con Ariana, y viendo películas que me gustan, fumo marijuana y me he dado cuenta que me viene muy bien, me hace un poco más consciente y me siento más expresivo y estoy menos obsesivo así que me ayuda. 

¿Qué más? Pues he entrado en programación, aunque tengo un conocimiento muy muy muy básico, estoy aprendiendo algo nuevo, y estirando mis capacidades un poco, y esto me inspira y me hace pensar que puedo aplicar esto en otras cosas. 

He también estado aprendiendo sobre mi resonancia vocal y articulación, hago unos ejercicios que me permiten mejorar la manera en que me comunico y eso está super bien. 

He podido leer libros, me leí Dialogue de Robert McKee, y he leído Zambra, y he leído también muchos artículos y me he puesto al día con the Browser, y the Hustle. 

¿Qué no ha ido tan bien? Pues me he enchismado con Yonah, me doy cuenta que puedo ser un poco frío o amargado a veces, me parece un poco triste que no tenga una dinámica o no comparta tanto con Elin o Nuria (que no me apetece) pero que siento que esto es tan importante que luego echaremos de menos. El cumpleaños de Nuria, cuando se «estropeo» la nevera de nosotros y conseguimos otras. Viendo el «dumpster fire» de Trump en EEUU. Hablando con Matt y Akash, hablando con mis primos Thomas, Lisa, Steven, con mis padres. 

El leer de the Hustle y ver la entrevista con Mic Faitos y conocer sobre Starbright flowers y enviarle flores a Ariana que aunque cuesten, es un buen gesto y sientes el poder de hacer negocios y ese sentimiento que da. 

El sacar el Chase Ultimate Freedom en tiempos de pandemia. El hecho que Nuria nunca sale de la casa, que Elin nunca sale de su cuarto, y que yo me paso haciendo recetas de Tasty y haciendo ejercicios que no duran ni 15 minutos. 

Ahora viene la gran pregunta: ¿qué es lo que yo quiero? ¿Qué es lo que me tiene tan aquí? 

¿Qué cosas me hubiese gustado haber hecho durante este mes? Si nada importará. 

Yo creo que una de las cosas sería aprender improvisación. Que creo que es una habilidad que me puede ayudar pensar en el momento y poder aprender como uno de mis heroes Stephen Colbert, aunque me gusta Jon Stewart y lo empecé a seguir más a él. 

Otra cosa que me hubiese gustado haber hecho durante este periodo es escribir. Creo que pudiera haber hecho algo un poco más profundo más allá de los artículos de “boredom is good!” bla bla bla sino algo que fuera un poquito más desafiante, como escribir un cuento corto. 

Quizás algo que me pueda dar un poco mas de ese COMMUNITY FEELING, y creo que si pueda confiarme con decir, mira esto es lo que yo hago, esto es lo que yo se hacer bien y este es el plan que yo tengo para enfrentar mi futuro y ser alguien que es INDEPENDIENTE FINANCIERAMENTE, y qué es alguien que sabe coquetear con mujeres, alguien que sabe expresar sus necesidad pero que también es poético, y alguien con una sensibilidad pero que a la misma vez es oscuro y no tiene miedo de mostrarlo. 

COMMUNITY FEELING

children.content: One way to [[follow your curiosity with a compost heap]] is by paying attention to naughty ideas. For example, Hunter Thompson's opening line in "Fear and Loathing" reads "We were somewhere in Barstow on the edge of the desert when the drugs began to take hold. I remember saying something like 'I feel a bit lightheaded; maybe you shoul ddrive...' And suddenly there was a terrible roar all around us and the sky was full of what looked like huge bats, all swooping and screeching and diving around the car, which was going about a hundred miles an hour with the top down to Las Vegas." The first line almost knocked me off my bed, and the appeal of Thompson's words came from this idea that I did't know anyone was allowed to write things like that. Going on a journey with a character who is paranoid and edging on insanity.

Ezra ve el mundo de políticas, donde ciencia se usa para motivos nefarios y continuar la discriminacion de un grupo. Hariss ve la ciencia como suprema realidad - La verdad científica es su Dios y pienso que es dogmático en esto, no que ser dogmático sea algo malo sino que es lo que es. Y aquí hay un choque de ideas.

Quien gana? Quien le importa. Ambos están cegados por sus propias creencias que no llega al 99.9999999% del mundo. Pero sus ideas lamentablemente si puede llegar al 99.999999% gracias a la tecnología así que, i tAke it back? De todos modos. Suicide.script y robiscript corren juntos ahora mismo.

> For what is “good” exactly? **In the literary world, ==much is about originality, finding an individual voice, uncovering what until now has been unseen—these are the ideals==.** Against this stands the concept of quality, the basis of all appraisal, and of any canonization. **==For when originality, individual voice, and the unseen come together there is nothing with which it can be compared.==** **There is no unequivocal way of saying that something is “good.”** When the book is there, with the publisher’s logo on the cover, that in itself is a stamp of quality: a large number of people with fine literary credentials, working in a well-reputed institution, have declared that this is literature, that this book is of value. To give a book that stamp of quality is a risky business. I have worked on manuscripts from first-time writers myself as an adviser and know how difficult it can be to judge quality on one’s own, without the bound book in one’s hand to testify that the criteria have been met. Is it good enough? What is good enough? And if it isn’t good enough, is there anything in it that can become good enough? ^^And if it happens to be very good, then there is nothing to which one can turn for comparison, **one is left to one’s own judgment—and is that good enough?**^^

Something that is very good implies that there is no one you can turn for comparison. So the only criteria that exists to determine is your judgement which Knausgård questions if even that is good enough.

Pensamiento del día ...

Siento que estamos viviendo en un punto crítico. Entiendo que el populismo y la popularidad de figuras autocráticas tiene mucho que ver con la realidad que hay muchos grupos hoy que no sienten que sus necesidades psicológicas se están cumpliendo. Yo siento que soy parte de esto, de que mis necesidades psicológicas no se están cumpliendo, pero no quiere decir que simpatizo con movimientos populistas que se ven hoy día. Pero es por suerte, porque yo fácilmente pude haber nacido en un entorno donde mis círculo y núcleo social me comunicara estas narrativas explicando porque estoy en la situación mierda que estoy. Entiendo que estos movimientos nacen de un amor y empatía profunda al prójimo. El odio es lo que ve el otro lado que no logra simpatizar con esta narrativa y con buena razón. Pero la polarización que suele llevar los medios y grupos políticos no sirve para resolver el problema. A lo contrario, son el problema. Para construir puentes, para evitar más sufrimiento y pérdida de vidas, es primordial y necesario, en mi opinión, saber que hay fuerzas y energías más allá que no están intentando comunicar unas realidades más profundas de las que podemos ver. Nuestra realidad esta nublada por capas y capas de prejuicios. Y muchos de estos prejuicios sólo sirven para beneficiar un grupo de poderes cual su interés es mantenernos en este estado. La jerarquía es producto inevitable de nuestro mundo pero eso no quiere decir que estamos a la merced de un mundo feudalista. La religión es nada más que una herramienta para alcanzar y imaginar unas realidades que no somos capaces de concebir. Yo sinceramente pienso que estamos viviendo en una nueva guerra mundial, y una que no estamos consciente. De aquí a 20 años (2038) digamos cual será el mundo que nos enfrentaremos? Una de las cosas que deseo que sea es que tengamos la inteligencia para reflejar y decir que fue un momento donde vivíamos en una guerra psicológica. Por falta de necesidades psicológicas (el ser parte de algo, el sentirse unido, etc) pero que está guerra viene provocada por una guerra de recursos. Tenemos más comida, más tecnología más cosas que en cualquier punto en la historia pero aún luchamos por recursos. Esta guerra psicológica se puede resolver. Primero hay que reconocer que el crecimiento de estos movimientos populistas reflejan un fallo en el sistema, y esa es mi opinión y mi prejuicio, pero este fallo en el diseño del sistema ha aumentado el riesgo de perder la humanidad. Porque estamos dando espacio a figuras con carácter violento y errático tomar decisiones sobre la vida de millones y millones de personas. Y lo que me entristece de todo esto es que las repercusiones de estos movimientos no se reflejarán hoy, cuando todo aparenta bien y la economía mueve como una máquina bien lubricada, sino que en un par de años, cuando el sistema esté sobre calentado y consumismo llegue a un punto que cause que todo explote. No tenemos el lujo de otra crisis, aunque sabemos que viene. Y viene pronto. ¿Entonces que hacer? Primero dar cara. Esto empieza ya, si esto es una guerra psicológica hay que primero reconocer de que sino estás luchando eres un territorio. En este caso un territorio capitalizable. Una figura. Un ente de consumo. Pero eres mucho más que eso. Eres un ser humano. Por lo que se puede ver. Aquella pieza que vive sobre tus ojos es la herramienta más poderosa en todo el universo. Si lográramos usar todas estas herramientas en conjunto para navegar a realidades más profundas, se que lograríamos lo impensable. Pero para llegar ahí tenemos que ir con un machete en el bosque, enfrentando monstruos y dar critica a cada pensamiento. Separado la verdad de la ficción.

Podemos construir las realidades que queremos vivir. Pero el conocimiento no sirve. Las experiencias es lo único que cuenta. Storytelling es una herramienta que disponemos para comunicar y construir realidades.
DDS- Cell- celda, es construir un mundo fantaseas a base de una celda y hacerlo en realidad. Y que transformes el conocimiento en una experiencia. Es lo que quiero.

JRE: 3, 2, 1 thanks for coming on the show.

JRE: what are you up to now, are you living in Barcelona? Puerto Rico? I think the last I heard you were in Barcelona. 
RS: I’m technically still in Barcelona, but I’m spending more time in PR. My home keeps calling me and every time I’m there I’m realize I love it, but it’s hard to figure out what to do in an island. 
JRE: It must be difficult when there’s hurricanes and storms and political uncertainty. 
RS: Exactly, also a lot of my friends are gone, my family is still there and I love them but the life I had and the life now just keep expanding like this expanding universe just moving out. 
JRE: So what’s the situation like there now?
RS: It’s a mess. We have a governor who succeeded him after he resigned because the secretary of state and everyone else was corrupt and she is also very corrupt but she was not involved in the scandal so it was her turn, and she was the secretary of justice, and the department of justice in PR, I’m sure like in other places as well, is basically this fascist government who goes after people who do anything that is not in line with their interests, so she is charge now and she is basically protecting the government officials in the scandal, so they’re fine for now, and now we have elections, and at the beginning she said she had no interest in running for re-election and now she is all about running for re-election and then we have another candidate who tried to force his way in to being a governor but couldn’t and he has a lot of money so he seems to be the guy who will come on top in november. It’s a fucking mess. 
JRE: So tell me about yourself. Where did you go to school? What was your life like?
RS: I grew up in Puerto Rico, went to Sarah Lawrence College because I wanted to be a writer, got very much involved in economics and sociology, graduated, traveled around for  bit, then moved back to PR, got into some trouble, was miserable, then moved to Barcelona and was working as a designer for a couple of years and here I am. 
JRE: Barcelona. I love it. 
RS: My whole thing right now is that I’ve been pretty uptight and just having a lot of self-control, I’ve always been the smallest in my family so I’ve been observant as a child and seen my brothers, sisters, get married, get divorced, take drugs, see my cousins go to jail for drugs, suicide, schizophrenia induced through pscyhedelics, and generally just terrible decision-making and my response to all of that has always been. I’m not going to be a fuck up like that, i’m not going to make the same mistakes as that. And inevitably, I do end up making mistakes. I do get into drugs. 
JRE: What was your drug of choice?
RS: I mean, I began drinking when I was about 14, I grew up in a household that celebrated getting drunk, and thought it was funny, I would buy rum when I was like 6 or 7 from stores, no problem at all, I used to compete in horseback riding when I was like 9 or 10 and one day i threw all my trainers cigarettes away and had to buy him some the next day, not a problem at all. I was never much into cigarettes, I smoked for a bit, but that was it, marijuana was my drug of choice for a while, especially in college, but then cocaine, which really gave me superhuman abilities for a bit, and caused hell for me later, and then MDMA and mushrooms and lsd, I think any progressive or curious minded people in drugs would probably follow the same path. 
JRE: Yeah, I’ve never done cocaine. 
RS: We know Joe, we know. 
JRE: this is great. did you learn anything from any of the psychedelic ones?
RS: Mushrooms was by far the most intense, it was like having epiphany after epiphany after epiphany just being bombarded by epiphanies one after the other, but then also just losing complete control of yourself so you start thinking you’re going mad and it was just massively anxiety inducing and yet there was so much truth and so much beauty happening at the same time, the thing about shrooms is that, a lot of people say its the most intense experience, and I agree, but the thing about shrooms is that I always knew I was tripping. 
JRE: Right. 
RS: Like there was not a moment where I was like this is going to be forever for me, because I knew I had ingested a chemical, and I felt like it would wear off eventually, we took a high dose and like four hours in we took another dose, because someone quit at the last minute, and I was trippin way into midnight but but then I was so exhausted and tired that I just put some headphones on listened to music and went to sleep. 
JRE: Still tripping?
RS: Yeah, and the next day I woke up, my mind felt like it had gone through a vitamix blender, and I was not fully myself but the trip was gone. And it was fine. It took me a few days to get myself together and understand everything that had happened but that was it. I mean, I had anxiety for a while, but I was just so miserable for the longest time, I felt like I was wasting my life away and needed to get away. 
JRE: you’re unemployed now right?
RS: Yup. I was working as a copywriter in Barcelona, I loved it but hated the work environment, very toxic. 
JRE: What would you like to do now? Like what’s your next project?
RS: So I’m thinking of moving to PR until the pandemic situation is under control. But then I would have to figure out what to do next. 
JRE: Right, what would that be? Like what is the thing that would change your life for the better?
RS: A steady income would be nice, but I also want to work on outrageous things. Because a lot of the people I know are just fine to settle for a mediocre existence.

Full quote: “Many people say they hope the dominant culture stops destroying the world,” as Jensen puts it, but by saying that, “they’ve assumed the destruction will continue, at least in the short term, and they’ve stepped away from their own ability to participate in stopping it.” ^^To give up hope, by contrast, is to reinhabit the power that you actually have. At that point, Jensen goes on, “we no longer have to ‘hope’ at all. We simply do the work.^^ We make sure salmon survive. We make sure prairie dogs survive. We make sure grizzlies survive … ^^When we stop hoping that the awful situation we’re in will somehow resolve itself, when we stop hoping the situation will somehow not get worse, then we are finally free—truly free—to honestly start working to resolve it^^
People sometimes ask Derrick Jensen, the environmentalist who cofounded the radical group Deep Green Resistance, how he manages to stay hopeful when everything seems so grim. But he tells them he doesn’t—and that he thinks that’s a good thing. Hope is supposed to be ^^“our beacon in the dark,” Jensen notes. But in reality, it’s a curse. To hope for a given outcome is to place your faith in something outside yourself, and outside the current moment—the government, for example, or God, or the next generation of activists, or just “the future”—to make things all right in the end^^
You could think of this book as an extended argument for the empowering potential of giving up hope. Embracing your limits means giving up hope that with the right techniques, and a bit more effort, you’d be able to meet other people’s limitless demands, realize your every ambition, excel in every role, or give every good cause or humanitarian crisis the attention it seems like it deserves
The key to what Pema Chödrön calls “getting the hang of hopelessness” lies in seeing that things aren’t going to be okay. Indeed, they’re already not okay—on a planetary level or an individual one. The Arctic ice is already melting. The pandemic has already killed millions, and crashed the economy. The question of how ill-qualified you can be for the American presidency yet still end up in the White House has already been definitively answered. Thousands of species are already gone
^^Abandoning hope is an affirmation, the beginning of the beginning,” Chödrön says. You realize that you never really needed the feeling of complete security you’d previously felt so desperate to attain. This is a liberation. Once you no longer need to convince yourself that the world isn’t filled with uncertainty and tragedy, you’re free to focus on doing what you can to help^^
^^Although another way of making the point that giving up hope doesn’t kill you, as Jensen points out, is that in a certain sense it does kill you. It kills the fear-driven, control-chasing, ego-dominated version of you—the one who cares intensely about what others think of you, about not disappointing anyone or stepping too far out of line, in case the people in charge find some way to punish you for it later. You find, Jensen writes, that “the civilized you died. ^^The manufactured, fabricated, stamped, molded you died. The victim died.” And the “you” that remains is more alive than before. More ready for action, but also more joyful, because it turns out that when you’re open enough to confront how things really are, you’re open enough to let all the good things in more fully, too, on their own terms, instead of trying to use them to bolster your need to know that everything will turn out fine

Giving up hope about something will free you from the idea of it. And when you free yourself from the idea of it, you also free yourself from the expectation it has on you. It is by giving this up that you can actually start working on it. This is what Pema Chödrön calls "getting the hang of hopelessness". This is also why you should [[let your impossible standards crash to the ground]].

blocks.page-name: no experience is in itself a cause of our success or failure

children.content: Etiology is the explanation of phenomena in terms of 'past causes' to explain a person's current behavior or unhappiness. Sigmund Freud believed these psychic wounds caused a person's present unhappiness. Another psychotherapist, Alfred Adler believed that trauma does not exist. In his book Fumitake writes, "Adler believes no experience is in itself a cause of our success or failure. We do not suffer from the shock of our experiences–the so-called trauma–but instead we make out of them whatever suits our purposes. We are not determined by our experiences, but the meaning we give them is self-determining. This focus on present 'goals' is known as teleology. You can think of someone who might experience anxiety before going to the dentist. Freud would say the anxiety comes from a past trauma. Adler, on the other hand, would argue that the subject is creating a state of anxiety to justify not going to the dentist. Therefore, not going to the dentist, the subject achieves his or her goal.
You can apply this idea to dealing [[writer's block]].
Adler's focus on present goals is similar to how [[existentialism emphasizes individual action]].
FUMITAKE, K. I. S. H. I. M. I. I. C. H. I. R. O. K. O. G. A. (2019). Courage to be disliked: How to free yourself, change your life and achieve real happiness. ALLEN & UNWIN. #[[Kishimi Fumitake]]

The young man’s brother had been killed in battle in 1940, before the French surrender; then his father had turned collaborator and deserted the family. The young man became his mother’s only companion and support. But what he longed to do was to sneak across the border via Spain to England, to join the Free French forces in exile and fight the Nazis —red-blooded combat at last, and a chance to avenge his brother, defy his father, and help to free his country. The problem was, it would leave his mother alone and in danger at a time when it was hard even to get food on the table. It might also get her into trouble with the Germans. So: should he do the right thing by his mother, with clear benefits to her alone, or should he take a chance on joining the fight and doing right by many?

Answer you are free: are you guided by moral laws ?
You are free no matter what your predicament is, and in choosing you determine who you will be. 

What you do really matters.

blocks.page-name: we buy stuff to repress the fear of death

children.content: We repress our fear of death by indulging in consumerism; buying the latest car, the newest iPhone, spending time in the shopping center, planning a two-week summer vacation. Søren Kierkegaard called it "shutupness", repressing the fear of death by lulling one's mind to the trivialities of work routines. What Kierkegaard also referred to as "tranquilizing itself with the trivial", and called such people "philistines". The problem with living life this way is that repressing the thoughts you are living in a lie.
Becker, Ernest. The Denial of Death. First Free Press Paperbacks Edition, Free Press, 1997. #[[Ernest Becker]]

blocks.page-name: most stories follow the hero's journey

children.content: The hero's journey is the common template for telling stories. The main character has a problem. They are living life in a self-perpetuating stasis, in need of change. Then the main character experiences an [[inciting incident forms an expectation of what the story is about]] that breaks their stasis, and are forced to undergo a journey that spits them out as a better person. This is a truncated version of Joseph Campbell's cherished Monomyth, and most stories follow it in some way or another.

As President, Ronald Reagan acted on the work habits of a lifetime: he regarded his daily schedule as being something like a shooting script in which characters came and went, scenes were rehearsed and acted out, and the plot was advanced one day at a time, and not always in sequence. Women don't want much. It's simple, in fact, and I have figured it all out. What women want is this...
Good company, someone who can make them laugh and babies. 
This is, in fact, quite easy to accomplish in the short term. We can make a wonderful impression and we can make babies if things go well. The problem is what happens after, when we talk about a second night. A third night. And so forth. When we talk about building a life together. It is no longer about romance but rather about survival. What do Women need from Men to ensure long term relationships? Well, the things we just said, but also need this, consistency, assertiveness. They need them not to get lazy. To be sure of themselves, to not be anxious, depressed. We all have our shitty days, we all get depressed, we all get anxious, we all get insecure. What do we do in these moments? Do we curl up and hope for the time to pass so we can better reorient ourselves? Or do we take a risk and take action to better guide our lives?

For the longest time I've beat myself up over why things didn't work out as planned. I placed myself on a pedestal, as the romantic dreamboat women so often crave about, I was handsome, rich, good looking, great company, I obsessed about the girl, so much that I took trips halfway across the world to surprise them. So what was wrong with me? Why didn't relationships last? It came to me not so long ago. You see, I placed myself on such a high pedestal that I wouldn't let anything near me, and as from this pedestal kicked away the ladder for true love to enter my life. It didn't take long for me to realize that as the great guy that I am, and with the good intentions in my heart to have true meaningful relationships, I'd also contribute to long list of shitty men women had encountered. It occurred to me one night, glossing over an ex Facebook that I realized that she had gotten in good terms with her previous ex boyfriend, a terror swept me underneath and suddenly felt the threat of her rejoining with a former flame, I got supremely jealous because after, part of the reason we had reconnected was from the damage caused by her previous boyfriend, now I was on the other side of the bench. As if trust was this beautiful tower we had constructed and now I was watching it burn down in flames, as if I had been tied down and force to watch this miraculous thing I had constructed go down to shit. I panicked, freaked out, I felt like jumping off from a building, too hard for me to bear. Then, suddenly, a single thought passed through my head that diffused the entire tension. It made all my worries and fears disappear in an instant. I thought to myself, I am the bad guy. Now suddenly I'm staring in front of my MacBook Pro talking to myself in a heavy Cuban accent  saying I'm the bad guy! Make way for the bad guy! I'm reciting the entire monologue from Tony Montana. I'm not going to buy Uzis and snort coke off of strippers buttholes but I definitely felt the powerful effect of recognizing id fucked up. I was embracing my failures, I was loving the fact that I hated myself. I even began to admire Trump, mind you, I would never ever ever vote for such a person, but I admired the fact that he is someone who takes pride in being hated. He knows he's a piece of shit human being, but he embraces it. The bad guy. Im now a bad guy. I'm evil. The focus and energy right now is amazing. My failures are dust. I'm speeding up ahead.

And I think this gets to the heart of the problem. We spend so much time obsessing about others people's problems, we rarely take the chance to look in at ourselves. She's a slut, she's a bitch, she's this, she's that. But I rarely take the time to be like, hey, I'm kind of a shitty person too, not always, not right now, but yeah I can be shitty, that makes me human. I masturbate a lot. These factors make me me. Let's be shitty together! Not in the vicious abusive relationship dynamic where we try to hide ourselves from each other and cause misery, but the this sucks, love sucks, but I'm here and you're here and let's do this together and we might not want to be together but we have each other's best intentions at heart, and well scream and fight but we will never abuse the trust and love for each other.

Once, not too long ago, I had the fortune of being able to attend a large music festival and it didn't take long for me to realize that there were a lot of people doing drugs, it's a good place to try to experiment and seek ways of expanding your mind. The trip in itself did not offer much to me but what I saw was somethings much more bigger. I realized that the festival in itself is a microcosm of radicalized utopian society. And in this radicalized utopian society there are two kinds of people. The people who are experimenting, that is, in a state of being where senses are heightened and you are fully vulnerable, you are at your most fragile state of being, you are pouring out everything you have within you and then there's the other person. The person who is not in this state, but who is there with you, who is feeding you positive affirmations, who is grabbing you by the shoulder and whispering in your ear, you are a great person, I love you, you are a gift of life to me. In this radicalized utopian society, these are the two kinds of people that exist. This is a gargantuan project to make happen, it is built entire in love, the musicians, the security, the reception, the janitors, the people who provide water, this entire universe this entire state of being is built so that we can get to experience moments like these. And when you leave the festival, when your serotonin levels are so fully depleted that you can't even crack half a smile, you know that in the back of your thoughts, in the back of it all, you have a mission, you have this power, you have this gift, to see someone who is in pain, who is in suffering, and give them the space to open up. This is your moment to let them shine.

Great writers don't write as if they have something important to say. Great writers write as if they have something important to show. This distinction is a key component to developing a strong sense of style.

Writers tend to show complex or difficult ideas by way of metaphors or analogies. Instead, rather than showing through metaphors or analogies, show by presenting actual instances that readers can see with their own eyes.

This is a way of arriving at truth, by use of symbolic language known as literature to share something true about the human experience.
Many young writers start out with the idea that a story is a place to express their views—to tell the world what they believe. That is, they understand the story as a delivery system for their ideas. I know I felt that way. A story was where I got to set the world straight and achieve glory via the sheer originality of my advanced moral positions.
			But, as a technical matter, fiction doesn’t support polemic very well. Because the writer invents all the elements, a story isn’t really in a position to “prove” anything. (If I make a dollhouse out of ice cream and put it in the sun, it doesn’t prove the notion “Houses melt.”)

blocks.page-name: dissect your scene to know how you're driving the story

children.content: A scene either drives action or triggers a turning point. To define the conflict, it helps to ask who drives the scene? Motivates it? And to answer these questions it helps to look at what the character wants. This is why it helps to [[pay attention to desire to understand the story]]. To define the conflict, you want to identify the *forces of antagonism* that stand in the way. Writers often frame the antagonism as an infinitive. For example, "the characters want to find the murderer; get the money. When you've identified what the character wants and the forces of antagonism, you can identify the _values at stake_ by looking at the positive and negative position of the value. Fourth, look at the opening and closing values of each in positive and negative terms. Finally, __survey beats__ and identify turning points.
McKee, Robert. Story: Substance, Structure, Style and the Principles of Screenwriting. , 1997. #[[Robert McKee]]

blocks.page-name: your mind is a story creation machine

children.content: Stories carry enormous psychological power because they are how the brain makes sense of information. Daniel Kahneman illustrates this with the words **Banana Vomit**. While the words have no relation to another, your mind assumes a temporal sequence, making a causal connection between the words bananas and vomit to create an image or story where a banana caused the sickness. **==Temporal sequence means that things happen linearly== and ==causal connection means that one thing caused the other to happen==**. The point to make here is that **your mind's ability to create ==stories serves to solidify abstract concepts and simplify complex messages==**.
Stories help to solidify abstract concepts and simplify complex messages.
According to Daniel Kahneman, what is the purpose of stories? #card
It assumes a temporal sequence, things happen linearly, and makes causal connections, one thing caused the other to happen.
What are two assumptions that the mind tends to make when creating a story? #card
Kahneman, Daniel. Thinking, Fast and Slow. 1st ed., Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 2013. Chapter 4 The Associative Machine #[[Daniel Kahneman]]

Philosopher Hannah Arendt used the words 'the banality of evil' to describe what she saw in the war criminal Adolf Eichmann. If something is 'banal', it is common, boring and unoriginal. Eichmann's evil was, she claimed, banal in the sense that it was the evil of a bureaucrat, of an office manager, rather than a devil. Here was this very ordinary sort of man who had allowed Nazi views to affect everything he did. Eichmann, like many Nazis during that era, failed to see things from someone else’s perspective. He wasn’t brave enough to question the rules that he was given: he simply looked for the best way to follow them. He lacked imagination. Arendt described him as shallow and brainless – though that too could have been an act.

Story: In 2009, Japan experienced its worst recession since World War II. The rise in unemployment triggered a panic wave which contributed to an uptick in suicides. Jumping in front of a train soon became one of the most common ways the suicides would play out. In a commuter culture like Japan, where train arrivals are tracked down to the millisecond, the suicides would cause long delays. To notify commuters of the delays, and to prevent stirring further panic, status monitors would attribute the delay to __jinshin jiko__, or "human accidents." It is rare to think that suicide is so pervasive in a culture that it causes visceral annoyance to the people whose routines are impacted by it. To curb train suicides, the Japanese rail companies proposed setting up screen doors that would physically prevent people from jumping in front of a train. But this proved to be way too expensive. Not only would it require billions in investment, but some train stations did not have the capacity to fit in a screen door. Then, something curious happened. Japan Rail began experimenting by installing soft blue lights along the stretches where the majority of the __jinshin jiko__ collisions would occur. Recognizing that suicide is more often than not, an act of impulse and emotion, the soothing effect of blue light would alleviate their psychological state and dissuade them from suicide. It turns out this simple solution led to an 84% drop of suicides in train stations. The installation of blue lights in Japan's train stations is what Rory Sutherland calls a __psychological moonshot__. Screen doors would have certainly made train stations safer, but these would have required enormous financial costs. The calming effect of blue lights, on the other hand, can help dissuade people from taking their lives while also making an ordinary train journey more enjoyable. In other words, __psychological moonshots__ are important because __it is easy to achieve massive improvements in perception at a fraction of the cost of equivalent improvements in reality.__ What psychological moonshots teach us is that the biggest progress we might have over the next 50 years might not come from improvements in technology, but rather in psychology and design thinking.

Rory Sutherland writes in his book __Alchemy__ about the idea of psychological moonshots:
collapsed:: true

> Making a train journey 20 per cent faster might cost hundreds of millions, but making it 20 per cent more enjoyable may cost almost nothing.The Uber map is a psychological moonshot because it does not reduce the waiting time for a taxi but simply makes waiting 90 per cent less frustrating.It seems likely that the biggest progress in the next 50 years may come not from improvements in technology but in psychology and design thinking. Put simply, it’s easy to achieve massive improvements in perception at a fraction of the cost of equivalent improvements in reality.

Now a love letter to yourself and a rejection letter to yourself:
Dear Robi,
I hope you are doing well.
I’m writing to tell you that I think you are going through a hard time right now.
No, it’s not the hard time as in going through a divorce or overcoming a heroin addiction, but it is the hard time of not knowing where to go.
I feel you.
I imagine you are rationalizing everything right now in hopes that the magical answer will present itself to you and make everything seem obvious and clear.
I’m sorry to tell you, but you are buying into a myth.
There are no easy answers.
What you want is a fantasy that will never happen.
That doesn’t mean you have to give up and succumb to the monotony of life.
But I just wanted to tell you that you don’t have to live like this.
You don’t have to live in this constant state of fear and dread.
You don’t have to erect these barriers in order to preserve the coherence of the ideas in your imagination.
Sometimes all you have to do is fall apart.
Falling apart means to stop buying into the narrative you have created for yourself.
Falling apart means to halt this never-ending pursuit of pleasure and avoidance of pain.
Falling apart means giving yourself the opportunity to be vulnerable, truly and completely vulnerable.
To feel the groundlessness of life and recognize that all of this is just one massive soup of atoms.
You are going to be OK.
You are going to be fine.
You have the power and the will to make the right decision.
You have the potential to be the person you know you are.
I love you.
What I love about you is your thirst for knowledge.
What I love about you is your ability to learn and read about new things.

What I love about you is your personality, you are nice, welcoming, forgiving, caring, kind, you take great care of yourself, you exercise, you eat vegetables like crazy, you sleep very well, you have great health, you are young, you have a knack for learning languages, you have a gift for words and writing, you practice and put your knowledge to the test, and you have a deep desire to help others.
Rejection letter:
Dear Robi,
I’m writing to let you know that I want a change.
I’ve had some marvelous years with you and I’ve treasured every minute of it.
But there comes a time where your life can go in either direction.
You can continue living the life you have now.
Or you can try something different.
That something different will come with growing pains.
You will need to expose yourself to the pain and discomfort of it.
You will be humiliated, taunted, and challenged for it.
But it will be a sign that you are doing the right thing.
I want to let you know that I don’t like the way you are living right now.
I don’t like that you have had to live your life in your own shell.
I don’t like that you have been low-balled and underestimated by people around you.
I don’t like that you have allowed doubt and worry to take control of you. That you have allowed it to make decisions for you.
I don’t like that you make empty promises.
I don’t like that you hide your true feelings. Your true beliefs.
I don’t like that you act like if everything is normal when it is not.
I don’t like it when you worry about trivial shit like “i took out the trash, why don’t they ever take out the trash?”
I don’t like it when you say you are going to go to Puerto Rico to start a project, and suddenly back out last minute and say you are going to stay.
I don’t like it that you say you will become a writer and yet you’ve never written a single thing that you are proud of.
I don’t like it when you say you are reader and yet you can’t remember anything.
I don’t like it when you masturbate every night because it is a way to feel less lonely than what you really are.
I don’t like it that you are living a life without purpose.
I don’t like it that you are 33 years old and have little to show for it.
I don’t like it when you begin projects and give up halfway.
I don’t like it when you waste your day in trivial crap like checking out your phone or seeing if you have a new match on Hinge.
This is why I want a change. I want to talk straight to you because I want you to be your best self. I want you to realize your potential as a human being.
I would like to see you commit to the things you say.
I would like to see you contribute to things I know you are capable of contributing.
I believe your potential can be great.
I believe your thirties can be infinitely more satisfying than your twenties.
You have a degree in Design Management. You know how to build products and services. You know the process required to build products and services.
I believe you can begin to realize your potential by waking up at a decent hour.
You can do it by writing and sharing your ideas and publishing them.
I see someone who has the potential to change. I believe in you.
I believe you have what it takes to be a Creative Director.
I believe in you.

children.content: __Sputnik Sweetheart__ (Japanese: スプートニクの恋人, __Supūtoniku no Koibito__) is a novel by [Haruki Murakami](https://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/HarukiMurakami), published in 1999. It follows the lives of three main characters through the eyes of one of them, and is largely concerned with the themes of love, loneliness, self-identity and the meaning of friendship. The lonely Sputnik satellites orbiting Earth serve as an ongoing piece of symbolism throughout the novel.

> And it came to me then. That we were wonderful traveling companions but in the end no more than lonely lumps of metal in their own separate orbits. From far off they look like beautiful shooting stars, but in reality they're nothing more than prisons, where each of us is locked up alone, going nowhere. When the orbits of these two satellites of ours happened to cross paths, we could be together. Maybe even open our hearts to each other. But that was only for the briefest moment. In the next instant we'd be in absolute solitude. Until we burned up and became nothing." [[Haruki Murakami]]

On our way to be a B Corp - story I care a lot, a business goes bad shit terrible when looking to become a b corp
 
After two days in the B Corp Summit in Amsterdam I got the inspiration, the energy and the empowerment to become a sustainability corporate activist. Activist? Oh, that sounds uncomfortable. 
 
Yes, that sounds like getting out of the confort zone.
 
But change only happens when there’s friction. 
There’s no business in a death planet, so we better face and deal with the change. A systemic and individual change. A shift of mindset, from a short term profit-focused one to a long term balance that puts the environment, the people and the profit at the same level.
 
Let’s no underestimate the importante of standing up, at a business and at an individual level. This climate emergency requires courage, leadership, collaboration, trust and empowerment of everyone of us. We’re the last generation of business that can do something about it. What we have to do in the next years is monumental. And your customers are expecting that you do something about it. 
 
The B Corp certification is a great starting point for any business: no matter if it’s a small or medium company or a large corporation.
It is an inspiring ecosystem and community of game-changing brands that are doing a great job in balancing the triple bottom line of planet, people and profit. Brands like Ecoalf, Tony’s, Goodwings, Ben&Jerry’s, Innocent Drinks, Patagonia, Fairphone, Veritas, Triodos Bank, HolaLuz… 
 
A total of 3.000 B Corps worldwide that are fighting for a common goal: to be the leading force of good. To move from an extractive “take-make-waste” business model to generative companies.
 
We all know that businesses are not perfect, and we will be making mistakes along the way. But as Jay Coen Gilbert, B Lab co-founder, mentioned in his final speech of the B Corp Summit, we have to start walking, and learn by doing. 
 
At Firma we are committed to be part of the change and are working hard to get the B Corp Certification in early 2020.
 
We are business strategists, we are innovators, we are creatives, we are digital experts. We have the tools and the resources to be heard. To build local consciousness. To recruit more agents of change. To challenge businesses as usual. To inspire industries that can force the needed regulations. 
 
Come join us on this. Things don’t just change. You have to make them change.

children.content: The minimum wage in Puerto Rico is $7.25 an hour. Local citizens working on a minimum wage salary are subject to an 11.5 percent tax. Aside from this, citizens are subject to an automatic 30 percent markup in prices that comes from all imports, which is owed to a large extent to the Jones Act. Because of [[Puerto Rico's Act 20 and Act 22]], the wealthy are exempt from paying taxes.
