Hace unos meses atrás escuché un podcast que me voló la mente. Se trata de un argumento desarrollado por Nick Borstrom, profesor de filosofía que abandera el Instituto del Futuro de la Humanidad en la Universidad de Oxford.

La idea es esta. Lo que tú y yo creemos que es en realidad, ósea todo la materia en nuestro entorno y toda la materia del universo, todas nuestras amistades, nuestra sensaciones, y nuestras experiencias no son reales sino es una simulación operada por una computadora. Esto quizás no te sorprenda tanto, sobretodo si ya has visto la película Matrix y estas familiarizado con esta idea. Pero el argumento de Borstrom no acaba aquí.

El argumenta que no solo estamos viviendo en una simulación, sino que esta simulación la esta corriendo nuestros descendientes en el futuro. Es importante reconocer dos cosas antes de entrar en lo que él quiere decir con esto.

Lo que hace esto tan interesante es que crea el espacio para poder cuestionar la realidad de nuestra naturaleza. Es un ejercicio filosófico que comienza desde los tiempos de Plato y la época del siglo 17 con Rene Descartes. Por cierto, Descartes inspirado por sus propias experiencias con los sueños, pensaba que vivíamos en una simulación creyendo que si la realidad es un sueño en sí, pues entonces no habría manera de separar la realidad de la ficción.

La segunda razón por cuál esta teoría atrae tanto interés es porque el autor no te esta diciendo en que creer. El autor no dice que estamos viviendo en una simulación sino que asume que es muy probable que estamos en una simulación. Es una pequeña distinción pero una que es importante ya que él esta planteando los distintos escenarios, dejando que lector llegar a su propia conclusión.
Dicho esto, podemos ahora entrar en la teoría de la simulación. La teoría de que es probable que estemos viviendo en una simulación en una computadora.

Para empezar, podemos asumir que la trayectoria tecnológica seguirá mejorando en el porvenir. Dudo que alguien cuestioné que las computadoras de mañana sean mejor de las que tenemos hoy. Vamos asumir que estos avances tecnológicos nos ayudarán sobrevenir los grandes retos que nos afectan hoy. Ósea el cambio climático, guerra nuclear, energía no renovable, etc.

En este caso, llegaremos a un punto en el futuro donde tendremos una capacidad computacional increíble, tan increíble para resolver los grandes retos, que ya en este entonces no tendrán propósito fijo. Esta tecnología se podría aplicar para hacer una simulación de la historía humana. Los motivos aquí pueden variar entre entretenimiento, estudio académico, interés histórico, etc.

Para poder creer esto hay que eliminar las restricciones del tiempo. Es decir, esto podría pasar de aquí a 10 años, 0 100 o en 1,000. Lo único que hay que asumir es que podría pasar en algún momento en el futuro, sin imponerle alguna restricción de tiempo. Con esto establecido ahora podemos entrar y profundizar sobre la teoría de la simulación.

Hay dos posibilidades aquí. O estamos viviendo en una simulación de nuestros descendientes del futuro, o no estamos viviendo en una simulación y lo que estamos experimentado es la realidad tal y como es.
Empecemos con el último. Si no estamos viviendo en una simulación eso implica que estamos ahora mismo viviendo en el siglo 21 en un planeta que nació alrededor de 3.5 mil millones de años atrás.

Esto tiene todo el sentido del mundo pero levanta dos preocupaciones. Una, nuestros descendientes del futuro tienen la capacidad computacional de correr una simulación de tal magnitud, pero no han decidido hacerlo. Tal vez nuestros descendientes del futuro tienen una obligación moral muy alta y jugar el papel de Dios va en contra de sus creencias.

Pero esta idea parece poco probable. SI miramos hacia el futuro podemos asumir que el planeta le queda millones de años, y si empezamos a colonizar otros planetas, pues la humanidad tendrá millones y millones de años por venir con millones y millones y millones y millones y millones de seres humanos por nacer. Esto implica que dentro de todo este transcurso de tiempo y todas las innovaciones y logros por venir, en ningún momento hubo una persona que se intereso en correr una simulación. Ni uno. Porque realmente lo único que requiere la teoría de la simulación para que sea válido es una persona. Por tanto, la probabilidad de que no estemos en una simulación por este motivo es muy muy baja.

Hay otra razón que explica porque no estamos en una simulación. Si no estamos en una simulación es porque no hay más seres humanos en el futuro. En este caso no hemos podido corregir y resolver los riesgos existenciales (cambio climático, guerra nuclear, etc.) y el proyecto humano llego a su final. En este escenario no hay seres humanos capaces de correr una simulación porque no los hay.

Pero no hay porque deprimirse. Si eres del creer que el ser humano puede resolver los riesgos existenciales y crees que nuestros descendientes pueden correr una simulación de tal magnitud pues tienes suerte. Hay una tercera opción. Al ser así, podemos decir que somos seres humanos viviendo en un universo simulado.

Ahora quizás estas pensando, de qué que importa si digo que estoy viviendo en la realidad o en una simulación, ambas son afirmaciones y no quieren decir nada. Pero si cambia algo, la simulación tiene una ventaja sobre la realidad.

Para ilustrar este punto miremos al juego de SIMS. Del año 2000 al año 2010, SIMS vendió alrededor de 125 millones de copias. Cada uno de estos usuarios descargo el juego en su ordenador, arrancó el programa y en un instante lanzó el universo SIMS. Cada versión del juego lanzaba su propia iteración pero cada una obedecía las mismas reglas y físicas que cualquier otra. Podemos imaginar una simulación como algo semejante a esto.

Ahora pensemos en cara al futuro. Imagínate si en algún momento en el futuro alguien crea un programa que sea capaz de crear un universo y que tenga éxito de ventas por 10 años alcanzando 125 millones de copias vendidas. Bajo este mismo escenario tú y yo tenemos una probabilidad de 1 en 125 millones de ser seres humanos reales. En otras palabras hay un 99.999999 por ciento seguro que tú y yo estamos viviendo en una simulación.

Pero queda ese uno. Es posible que seamos los primeros seres humanos, los genuinos pero esto también tiene un problema. Eso sería lo mismo que decir todos somos Napoleon pero en realidad solo existió un solo Napoleon. El problema aquí es que no hay base de referencia para separar la realidad de la simulación.

Hay que reconocer, también que esto no cambia nada. El universo no ha cambiado y las leyes de física siguen siendo las mismas. Tu madre sigue siendo tu madre. Este ensayo no te otorga poderes especiales para atravesar una nueva dimensión.
Pero lo que sí puede ofrecer esta teoría es un cambio de perspectiva.

En el 2017, un grupo de investigadores de la Universidad de Oxford corrieron un experimento que pareció invalidar la idea de que vivimos en una simulación, mostrando que es físicamente imposible simular un aspecto del universo.

El experimento invalida la teoría de la simulación en base al efecto Hall cuántico. El efecto Hall cuántico describe la manera en que los electrones navegan entre estados de energía conocido como salto cuántico en presencia de un campo magnético y temperaturas muy bajas.

El punto es que el efecto Hall cuántico muestra que por cada partícula que se añade al modelo requiere duplicar el poder computacional cada vez. Por lo tanto, correr una simulación, aunque sea un aspecto del universo sería físicamente imposible.

Esto es por un lado. Por el otro lado, el hecho de que podamos observar el mismo efecto Hall cuántico en nuestro propio universo también sirve como evidencia de que no estamos viviendo en una simulación.

Pero esto no es el final de la historia. Los mismos investigadores concluyeron que la simulación no es posible con las computadores que tenemos hoy día. Las computadores que usamos hoy requieren electrones para transferir información.

En el caso de que en el futuro tendremos computadores más avanzadas, que es muy probable, podremos entonces abordar esta limitación. Sería de las cosas más sorprendentes que en el futuro no tendremos computadores más avanzadas y sofisticadas de las que tenemos hoy día.

Las computadores cuánticas nos pinta una imagen de cómo podría ser este futuro. A contrario de computadores tradicionales, las computadoras cuánticas no transfieren información por electrones sino por la interacción de partículas elementarias.
La capacidad computacional de computadores cuánticas permite llevar el efecto Hall cuántico de lo imposible a lo posible.

En todo esto, aún no hemos abordado sobre el tema de la conciencia y lo que es la realidad subjetiva. En un trabajo académico (Pastor) se estimo que un cerebro humano puede procesar alrededor de 10 a las 17 operaciones por segundo. Esto parece crear la unidad de proceso requerida para simular la experiencia subjetiva. Ahora multiplica 10 a las 17 por 170 mil millones de seres humanos (todos los humanos que han existido hasta hoy día) y tenemos una simulación.

Y ni siquiera tendría que ser tan grande. Lo que requiere es una computadora capaz de ejecutar operaciones de 10 a las 17 multiplicado por 10 mil millones por segundo. Esto no incluiría el universo simulado pero sí podríamos crear una percepción del universo para que parezca real.

No estamos ni cerca de tener una computadora de esta magnitud. En el 2014 la corporación Fujitsu corrió un experimento con su computadora K, conocida como la cuarta computadora más avanzada en el mundo. Los ingenieros querían ver cuánto se tardaría la computadora en procesar un por ciento del a información que puede procesar el cerebro humano en un segundo.

Se tardo cuarenta minutos para completar la tarea. No solamente se tardo cerca de una hora para procesar un por ciento de información en el cerebro humano sino que consumió alrededor de 12.7 megawatts de electricidad que equivale a toda la energía que consume la ciudad de Sacramento, California.

Pero esto también es una cuestión de tiempo. Si miras como hemos crecido en los últimos treinta años comprueba el paso exponencial del poder computacional de las computadoras. Por ejemplo, en el 1985, la mejor computadora era del tamaño de un coche y podía llevar 250 millones de operaciones por segundo. Treinta años mas tarde tenemos el iPhone que es capaz de operar más de 600 mil millones de operaciones por segundo y cabe en tu bolsillo.

El gran problema para la simulación es que necesitamos un marco de referencia. Los físico están empezando a llegar a este punto. Mientras que antes pensábamos que la materia más pequeña sería el átomo (quiere decir materia indivisible), ahora estamos empezando a conocer mas sobre el longitud de Planck o hondón. Para ilustrar cuán pequeño es un hondón, un átomo es el tamaño de una galaxia. Esto puede empezar a destapar algunos de los misterios pero aún no sabemos mucho sobre la realidad de nuestra naturaleza.

Si da el caso que somos una versión simulada capaz de crear simulaciones también corremos en otro problema. Porque esto implica que si sabemos que podemos correr simulaciones entonces podríamos estar en una simulación dentro de otras simulaciones. Aquí entraríamos en el problema que se conoce como “regresión infinita.”
Una implicación de todo esto es que vivimos en una infinita espuma de burbujas, cada burbuja siendo su propio universo y cada universo siendo un sistema aislado.

Otro tema aquí es el tema de quién es nuestro “creador”. En este caso no tendríamos que entregar a una creencia religiosa o en un ente sobre natural. Si somos simulados sabemos quienes nos crearon, los humanos del futuro.

Pero al ser así habría que pregunta, quién exactamente es el desarrollador de este program? El argumento de la simulación no comprueba nada de la realidad percibida, simplemente es una herramienta para entender la naturaleza de nuestro universo.

Nosotros somos el resultado de un proceso físico que logro convertir materia muerta en vida celular, y de aquí salir moldeado por las fuerzas de evolución. El sentido sale de lo que uno crea en el proceso. Siento esto una simulación o no no cambia nada, los retos que enfrentamos siguen siendo reales pero podemos verlo con una cara distinta para ver cómo resolverlos.
Como efectivamente redactar una nota de agradecimiento.

Elogiar funciona mejor cuando es especifico. Esta misma regla aplica en nuestras relacionas, mientras más nuestra pareja dice sobre que es lo que aprecia de nosotros, más real se siente su afección. Es cuando han estudiado la forma de nuestros dedos, cuando reconocen las idiosincracias de nuestro carácter, que el elogio empieza a contar. La persona que ha organizado una cena o enviado un regalo no es nada distinto. Ellos también tienen ansias por elogios en su formas especifica sobre genérica. No tenemos que ser artistas de renombre para efectivamente redactar una carta de agradecimiento, solo tenemos que localizar y aferrarnos fuertemente a dos o tres razones detallas de nuestro agradecimiento .

“Praise works best the more specific it can be. We know this in love; the more a partner can say what it is they appreciate about us, the more real their affection can feel. It is when they’ve studied the shape of our fingers, when they’ve recognised the quirks of our character, that the praise starts to count. The person who has given a dinner party or sent us a present is no different. They too hunger for praise in its specific rather than general forms. We don’t have to be great artists to send effective thank you notes: we just need to locate and hold on tightly to two or three highly detailed reasons for our gratitude” (711 words)
Realización fría

Más que ver ciertos programas de televisión, elegimos ver Netflix. Más que escuchar canciones, elegimos escuchar a Spotify. Más que leer ciertos libros, elegimos leer nuestros Kindles. De aquí podemos elegir a no prestar atención a los detalles. Marshall McLuhan argumenta que cada medio contiene otro medio pre existente como su medio. Discurso es el contenido de escritura, mientras que la escritura es el contenido de lo impreso. Lo impreso, tanto como la música y el video, se han convertido en el contenido del internet. Las películas y la televisión se han convertido en el contenido de Netflix. La plataforma que se aprovecha de nuestra desorientación y elige el comportamiento por nosotros.

Cold Discovery
Drew Austin | Real Life | 10th December 2018
“More than watching certain shows, we watch Netflix; more than listening to songs, we listen to Spotify; more than reading particular books, we read our Kindles. We can choose not to pay attention to the details beyond that. Marshall McLuhan argued that every medium contains another pre-existing medium as its content: Speech is the content of writing, while writing is the content of print. Print, along with music and video, has become the content of the internet. Movies and television have become the content of Netflix. The platforms take advantage of our disorientation and choose behaviour for us” (3,277 words)

tosUn agente literario explica porque no deberías escribir ese libro. Es mi trabajo a jornada completa para encontrar nuevos trabajos y ayudar que se publiquen. Cuando la gente habla de “tienen una idea para un libro”, o cuando otros dicen que deberían de escribir un libro (que es mi pesadilla), lo que ellos realmente quieren decir es, “yo apuesto que alguien, pero probablemente yo no porque ya lo he escuchado, te pagaría dinero para escuchar esta historia.” Esto es lo que ellos nos sabe, y que probablemente ningún escritor comenzando sabe, tampoco.”

You Probably Don’t Have A Book In You
Kate McKean | Outline | 25th July 2018 
A literary agent explains why you shouldn’t write that book. “It is my full-time job to find new books and help them get published. When people talk about ‘having a book in them’, or when people tell others they should write a book (which is basically my nightmare), what they really mean is ‘I bet someone, but probably not me because I already heard it, would pay money to hear this story’. Here’s what they don’t know, and what most beginner writers might not realize, either” (1,100 words)
Julio 1, 2020
Dear Marc,

I just want to say that I don’t like you. I think you are not beneficial to society, and I abhor the way you treat others. You take advantage of others, when someone aims to contribute, you focus on the negative aspects and then reprimand them for being negative. You seek perfection and treat others like shit. I don’t think you’re xenophobic, but you do think of yourself as superior to others. You are arrogant, self-centered, narcissistic, and think everyone else is to blame. I would love nothing more than to see you crash. I hope karma comes your way. I hope the world

I don’t know what drives you to be such an asshole. Your greed, your need to treat others like shit and look down upon them. Your attitude is hurtful but it will not stop me. I want to thank you, because thanks to you I realize that I’m meant for something greater than swindling people to consuming crap. Thanks to you I no longer have to slog away my days in a minimum payment so you can cash in. Thanks do you I have so much more to live and so many opportunities ahead. Thanks to you I am free. Thanks to you I can find my own path, and I don’t have to deal with your poor behavior. I dislike you. I dislike your way of treating people. I dislike your business model. I dislike your belittling of others. I dislike everything about you. I really do. I can’t believe people have to put with your shit. You are hurtful, mean. You are an asshole. You are obnoxious, you are aggressively obnoxious. Anton is manipulatively insincere. You guys don’t have an inch of what I can offer.

You might think that I need you more than you need me. But I find that hard to believe. I think you need me more than I need you. I won you Mobile, I won you Esade, I won you LE Tribute, and I won you much more than you could have ever hoped. Yes, you had the client, but I put in the work. And now, I hope they criticize all the typos and crap. I’m thankful for the fact that I no longer have to justify one more decision, and I truly wish you get what you deserve. You are a scumbag, and I will do everything in my power to ensure that I never have to work for someone like you. You take advantage of people, and then you spit them out so you can take advantage of others. I may only have words right now, I wish there was more action that I could take, and I definitely could take action. But I’m not seeking revenge, I’m looking to get even. And I will get even given the opportunity.

Getting even is what drives me right now. It is what pushes me and motivates me. I don’t do it to prove you wrong, I do it for me. You mean nothing me. Getting even would be for you to feel regret at the way you treated me and the way you treat others. Getting even would be that I get what I deserve.
Get the funk out my face. You had your chance, get the funk out my face.
Estimado Marc:

Te escribo porque me gustaría cerrar este capítulo de mi vida y aún no he tenido la oportunidad de expresarme. Estoy sumamente agradecido por Anton, por haberme brindado la oportunidad de unirme al equipo. En los primeros meses sentía que tenía un gran propósito, al yo haber estudiado en Nueva York, haber vivido en Alemania, y haberme graduado en un programa de diseño y con mis experiencia en Domestic y Bestiario, sabía que tenía mucho que aportar a Firma. Encima de todo, me sentía una gran responsabilidad de definir el departamento de copy, ya que este puesto no existía anteriormente y correspondía a mi a que todo se encaminará. Por eso fue que desde el comienzo en ningún momento le decía no a nada. Pensaba que no era una señal de debilidad y no quería decepcionar a nadie. Hoy, luego de varios meses en silencio, siento que eres tu el que me has decepcionado. No solo he estado involucrado en el 90% de los proyectos en Firma, pero he sobrellevado tareas y trabajos para dar el mejor resultado. Siento un gran alivio de no estar bajo tu mandato, porque creo que eres una persona totalmente desorganizada que pone el ego sobre capacidad. No sabes lo que acabas de hacer y espero que algún día te des cuenta y te arrepientas. Has tenido la oportunidad de oro y la has cagado. En más de una ocasión me has humillado, indebidamente, y nunca te disculpaste. Y ahora el que tiene que sufrir las consecuencias soy yo. Pues me parece injusto, y si, aunque se que el mundo es injusto, y que la justicia es una ficción, siento que deberías de pagar por lo que has hecho. En ningún momento te disculpaste y esperabas que yo siguiera willy nilly como si todo estuviera bien. Es una falta de respeto, es una falta de humanidad, y me parece una poca vergüenza en la manera que te comportas. Das mucha vergüenza, y espero que tarde o temprano se den cuenta. Una empresa que se aprovecha de la buena voluntad de otros no me parece como un modelo sostenible. No quiero decir que eres una mala persona, pero sinceramente eres un idiota. La has cagado de una manera increíble y que el resto sepan que no sirves. Espero que te forres porque tus hijos te van odiar, y todo el mundo alrededor tuyo te va odiar también. Me caes genuinamente mal y espero que te toque lo que te mereces sin vergüenza.

blocks.page-name: time is not a commodity you possess

children.content: Treating time like a commodity creates this false idea that time is something you can possess. When it is something we think we possess we begin to focus our time on the value it will have for future purposes. I will do X today so I can enjoy Y in the future. This fixation to use time for future purposes, however, is motivated by the desire not to die.

Jorge Luis Borges once claimed that “Time is a river that sweeps me along, but I am the river; it is a tiger which destroys me, but I am the tiger; it is a fire which consumes me, but I am the fire.” There’s no scrambling up to the safety of the riverbank when the river is you. ^^And so insecurity and vulnerability are the default state—because in each of the moments that you inescapably are, anything could happen, from an urgent email that scuppers your plans for the morning to a bereavement that shakes your world to its foundations^^
Burkeman, O. (2021). Four Thousand Weeks: Time Management for mortals. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. #[[Oliver Burkeman]]

Lightning round Q’s:
I’m good. It’s a crummy day, there’s a tropical storm but I’m good. I had sex last night, so that’s good.
How are you doing today?
I understand. Let’s smooth into it haha.
Yes, yes. Of course. Let’s get started. I don’t want to freak you out with a serious question, but I have tons of them.
Yes, that is correct. I did a year and three months at a branding and innovation firm in Barcelona.
Ok, ok. You were working as a copywriter, is that correct?

It was nice. Lots of young attractive people, I got to walk to work each day because it was fifteen minutes away, but it was really nice. That was what I enjoyed. I didn’t like other things, however. There was no copywriting department before, and I was constantly overwhelmed, I had to put on like 6 different hats each day. Being the voice of a brand for a car company, then a hip juice company, then an alcoholic beverage brand, then a cosmetic. The bad thing about all of that was that I never even tried any of these products, and when it’s things like cosmetic, the wording has to be very precise. It was very annoying because of course sometimes you commit typos, especially when there’s a lot of work and no time for review, but I got a lot of slack for things that weren’t typos, just no prior knowledge of the product, but that got passed off as a typo, and I got in trouble. It was very frustrating because whenever something good happened, the credit went to the strategist, or the designer, but whenever something bad happened, well I got the punishment. It was very toxic, and in a way, I’m very happy I’m gone, in another way, I’m disappointed and feel like I was taken advantage of. So now I’m looking forward to the next thing.
And how was that?

Well, my girlfriend and partner is staying in Puerto Rico for the time being, and right now I’m jobless and pretty much drifting, I have no clue what I’m doing, to be honest, but I’m thinking of moving back to Puerto Rico even though it will be a major culture shock. My girlfriend is here, my family is here, I’m turning 33, I feel a bit old and I’m constantly anxious about my future, my financial future especially, seeing as how many of my friends are already married and have kids. I know that is BS, but still I can’t help feel like I’m not really making the most of my life.
What is that next thing?

So I’ve been in Barcelona for about four years now, and it’s extremely frustrating job-wise. quality of life is superb, but honestly my friends just get drunk and do drugs pretty much every weekend. I don’t partake, I’ve been off alcohol for five months and recently picked it up which I’m not proud of because it’s not helping my self-esteem or my confidence, but yeah Barcelona is just get drunk, get drugged, hook up, which sounds amazing and I’m sure for many it is, but it is also very depressing. It’s like your life hasn’t progressed since high school, and you think you’re doing a lot of amazing things, but really you’re just an overgrown kid and emotionally stunted. That’s one side, the other side is enjoying the outdoors, the amount of safety and security in the city, and then there’s the elitism. It’s all about the pros and cons. But I’ve been doing that for about 3 and a half years, going to four, and I definitely feel like it’s time for a change.
And you think moving to PR will help you get there?

I mean, I love what you do haha. I love asking questions, I love researching topics, and I love finding things that other people have not found out. I recently did a personality test and I think a lot of that is BS you know, but I did it and I got the “thinker” type, you see, I’m a thinker, I spent a lot of time in my own thoughts, I love that, I’ve actually done the test a few times and the same thing pops up, so it’s pretty consistent. My ideal job would be to work with people I care about, but also having the freedom to work from home, and being able to create things that people thought they didn’t need but they really love once they see it. I don’t want no mediocre bullshit. I want something that’s real. Right now with the pandemic it’s very difficult to get something going, but hopefully something soon.

So it sounds like a lot of what’s pulling you back is your job, an inability to find a job, so what would your ideal job be, let’s say Barcelona is Barcelona, but you have the option to decide what you will contribute. What would that be? Paint me a picture.

Yeah, writing is my thing. Ever since I read Hunter Thompson’s Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas and Anthony Bourdain’s Kitchen Confidential, I’ve always been so intrigued by magazines and journals, but people nowadays don’t read and the publishing model is so broke and destroyed that to think of making a career in publishing is becoming ever and ever harder. Content is still massively important, it’s just the delivery systems have changed, and in our social media world people don’t even pay attention to how news feeds are turning our brains into slushee. But I like the whole creating a brand, creating a business or idea, so I thought about working in creating brands as I contineue to build my skillset in web development.
You also look like you love to write.
Yes, please. Fire away.

Great. Listen there seems to be a lot here and I don’t even know where to begin. You seem to me like someone who is very curious about the world, you definitely love to learn, your empathetic, you care about others and you have experiences that could help you guide you in the right path. I understand the job market is very hard right now, and you have to figure out a way, which I know you will. You will find your path, I know it. But I would like to ask you some other questions and maybe we can get back to that. Is that ok?

That’s a fantastic question. Intelligence obviously means may different things, right, there’s applied intelligence, how well you can solve problems, there is theoretical intelligence, your knowledge in books and topics and how well you can share them to others. Intelligence if I have to put it in the simplest way is whatever improves our context of our world, and world I mean loosely as in our perception of reality and everything around us. So intelligence is just anything that allows me to have predictive power. I think there are people who might mistake intelligence for truth, but that is what intelligence is for me. We live in a world where we are desperate for meaning, desperate for context, so we plug our eyes and our ears to our screens, hoping for an insight or some bit of information that might give us an upper hand in the world when really we’re just running in circles. That’s not intelligence. That’s stupidity. We feel intelligent, we feel like we are gaining something, but that is not it. Intelligence is about sharpening your insight and applying it to improve yourself and those around you. How do you apply it in your day to day? That’s a very subjective question. Whatever your field is in. I’m always looking to learn or read something new, and I know that sounds contradictory with what I just said, but I’m looking it from the perspective of something that challenges my understanding of the world. And that is the key difference. Instead of just hopping along, I’m looking for something that will question my assumptions of the world, to make me realize how much of a noob I am, when I get there, that’s when I know I’m applying my intelligence. It’s not something that will give me a raise or make me realize how smart I am in front of others, nothing like that, it’s personal. It makes me see how wrong I am in a lot of things. In that sense, I feel like I still have a lot to learn and what I try to do is use that to improve my understanding of the world.
What do you is intelligence and how do you think you can improve your intelligence in your day to day living?

Ok, so just now I was telling you about intelligence, and my mind quickly jumps to this rolodex of topics relating to intelligence and books about intelligence I’ve read. I’ve not read much on the science of intelligence, but I am familiar with transhumanist Ray Kurzweil and other productivity experts who have broken down this topic and atomize it to make sense of the world. And what I was going to say was basically parroting what someone else is written, which they are qualified to talk about because they are successful, but some of them are also lucky, right? Happiness is difficult to measure because of the problem of false consciousness. False consciousness is a way of thinking that prevents a person from perceiving the true nature of their social or economic situation. This bears relation to [[plato's cave is about the value of pursuing an examined life]] or its more modern incarnation in the film the Matrix. Some people, like Morpheus, see a life under false consciousness as unacceptable. Others, like Cypher, prefer to live in false consciousness than risk a hard and dangerous life of resistance in reality. Who are we to say that Cypher's choice is the wrong one? What right does Morpheus have to rescue people only to make them feel miserable? Chang writes, "we should not approve of an unequal and brutal society because surveys show that people are happy. But who has the right to tell those oppressed women or starving landless peasents that they shouldn't be happy, if they think they are? Does anyone have the right to make those people feel miserable by telling them the 'truth'? There are not easy answers to these questions, but they definitely tell us that we cannot rely on 'subjective' happiness surveys to decide how well people are doing. This is why happiness is difficult to measure because it is a genuinely difficult problem that has no definite solution.
Chang, Ha-Joon. By Ha-Joon Chang Economics: The User’s Guide: A Pelican Introduction (Pelican Books). Pelican, 2014. #[[Ha-Joon Chang]]

> The place is presided over by a wiry ramen master rocking a blond, boy-band coif, who dances around behind the counter, boiling and draining and plating his food with the percussive flamboyance of a flair bartender. 
Tsukemen is a type of ramen in which the cold, cooked noodles are served separately, on a plate, with a bowl of broth on the side—a dish meant to be eaten with precision, in deliberately constructed bites of noodles dipped in the broth, then slurped up.
We waited outside for 30 to 40 minutes in the rain in the early phase of a typhoon in order to eat at Fuunji. 
I waited for ramen—for a lot of ramen, and especially for one particular bowl, at Ginza Kagari, a tiny counter in the labyrinth of the Ginza subway station. 
There’s a phrase in Japanese for places like this⎯gyouretsu no dekiru mise: “restaurants that have very long lines.” ^^The lines are often self-fulfilling prophecies: The wait isn’t part of the cost, as I’d always considered it; to a Japanese person, it’s part of the value.^^

The inconvenience of waiting for something can be its own reward. It helps build expectation, and the more you wait for, the more you will cherish it and enjoy it. In Tokyo, for example, it is not uncommon to wait 30 to 40 minutes in line to eat tsukemen, a type of ramen in which the cold, cooked noodles are served separately, on a plate, with a bowl of broth on the side. The dish is meant to be eaten with precision, in deliberately constructed bites of noodles dipped in the broth, then slurped up. The Japanese have a phrase for this tradition, *youretsu no dekiru mise*: "restaurants that have very long lines." ^^The lines are often self-fulfilling prophecies: The wait isn’t part of the cost, as I’d always considered it; to a Japanese person, it’s part of the value.^^

> Quote: Around 1917, the Russian literary critic and revolutionary Victor Shklovsky wrote an essay on __ Don Quixote__, and in particular on the genesis of its mythic hero. Shklovsky argued that [Cervantes had begun his novel as a series of episodes with a gimmick: a character who couldn’t distinguish between reality and fiction]. It was only by following this screwball joke for episode after episode that he had come up with something much deeper and rarer. ^^He had created the complicated figure of Don Quixote, therefore, not before he began but in the process of writing his book^^. As he continued to think through its giant length, Cervantes happened on a new invention: a character who was fuzzy with ambiguity, a study in self-deception, illusion, and unreality, both comical and noble, who begins the history of the modern European novel.

The meaning of your story and your characters will appear not in the ideas you have before writing, but in the process of writing itself. One way to kickstart this process is by starting with a joke or gimmick. This is what the Russian literary critic Victor Shklovsky believed lead to the creation of Don Quixote, and consequently the modern European novel. As Adam Thirlwell argues, "Cervantes begun his novel as a series of episodes with a gimmick: a character who couldn't distinguish between reality and fiction. It was only by following this screwball joke for episode after episode that he had come up with something much deeper and rarer. He had created the complicated figure of Don Quixote, therefore, not before he began but in the process of writing his book. As he continued to think through its giant depth, Cervantes happened on a new invention: a character who was fuzzy with ambiguity, a study in self-deception, illusion, and unreality, both comical and noble."

children.content: The fetus.
In Judith Jarvis THomson's thought experiment, what is the violinist a metaphor for? #card

Judith Jarvis Thomson's paper, "A Defense of Abortion" invites the reader to imagine a violinist whose only chance of survival is to be plugged into a person who shares his very rare blood group. Now imagine that your blood group matches that of the violinist. Because of this match, the doctors decided to attach you to the violinist. You were asleep when they did this and did not notice. Now the life of the violinist is in your hands. Are you morally obligated to keep the violinist plugged to you? Do you, by obligation, now have to spend every waking moment attached to this violinist? Thomson argues that you are not morally obligated. As Warburton explains, "in this same way, [Thomson] suggests, if a woman is pregnant even though she used contraception, the developing fetus inside her does not have an automatic right to use of her body. The fetus is like the violinist."
Warburton, Nigel. A Little History of Philosophy. Yale University Press, 2011. #[[Nigel Warburton]]

children.content: Machine learning reflects the categories of official thought. As such, it also interprets the policy consequences of these categories too, which ultimately leads to compounding bias. This is why the technologist [Maciej Ceglowski](https://idlewords.com/talks/sase_panel.htm) describes machine learning as "money laundering for bias" since the algorithms end up creating incentives for ever more distorted ways of understanding the world, enabling these feedback loops that get progressively worse over time. The fear here is that greater dependence on these mechanisms sets up a higher risk of not just human tragedy, but also giving way to authoritarian systems.

Why does freedom require responsibility? card
Because by existing, you are free to choose how to respond to everything that happens to you. That is, you need to own up to your actions if you want to be free.

Quote: ^Freedom, for him, lay at the heart of all human experience, ^^and this set humans apart from all other kinds of object. But as a human being, I have no predefined nature at all. I create that nature through what I choose to do. Of course I may be influenced by my biology, or by aspects of my culture and personal background, but none of this adds up to a complete blueprint for producing me. I am always one step ahead of myself, making myself up as I go along. Sartre put this principle into a three-word slogan, which for him defined existentialism: ‘Existence precedes essence’. But roughly it means that, having found myself thrown into the world, I go on to create my own definition (or nature, or essence), in a way that never happens with other objects or life forms. Even if the situation is unbearable — perhaps you are facing execution, or sitting in a Gestapo prison, or about to fall off a cliff — you are still free to decide what to make of it in mind and deed. Starting from where you are now, you choose. And in choosing, you also choose who you will be. He heightens this anxiety by pointing out that what you do really matters. You should make your choices as though you were choosing on behalf of the whole of humanity, taking the entire burden of responsibility for how the human race behaves.^^ If you avoid this responsibility by fooling yourself that you are the victim of circumstance or of someone else’s bad advice, you are failing to meet the demands of human life and choosing a fake existence, cut off from your own ‘authenticity’. As Sartre summed it up in an interview shortly after the lecture: There is no traced-out path to lead man to his salvation; he must constantly invent his own path. But, to invent it, he is free, responsible, without excuse, and every hope lies within him.^^

Existentialism emphasizes individual action. You are influenced by your biology, environment, culture, and past experiences, but at the same time you are also making choices every single minute of the day. The fact that you are alive and making choices means that you create nature, you create the world by the actions you take now. Jean-Paul Sartre takes this one step further, even if you are in a situation where there is no choice for you to make, like facing an execution or diagnosed with a terminal disease, you are still free to choose what to make of it. It is in choosing that you decide who you are and who you will be. Therefore, freedom is at the heart of human experience and what sets us apart from all other creatures. This, however, requires responsibility. It requires owning up to your decisions and being responsible for them. It is a philosophy of responsibility because it does not have room for blame or victimization.
The philosophy of [[Heidegger paved the way for existentialism]].
Bakewell, Sarah. At the Existentialist Café: Freedom, Being, and Apricot Cocktails. , 2016. Print. #[[Sarah Bakewell]]

Ahora otro tema que quiero hablar y es el del referéndum catalán. Un tema muy controversial y la verdad que no se mucho porque ya no estoy en barcelona pero quiero formar mi opinion a cuanto esto porque parece relevante a lo que esta sucediendo en el mundo y aunque todo el mundo tiene su opinion, yo quisiera tener claro para mi mismo donde yo me paro en este asunto.

Los catalanes no son muy inteligentes en mi opinion, son industriosos y tiene una mentalidad dirigida hacia el comercio y de ganar, que es algo que respeto pero son un poco descarados en mi opinion. Lo que no entiendo y lo que no estoy a favor en todo esto es porque la única opción para Cataluña es declarar una republica. Cual es la obsesión con la republica? Es un sistema viejo. Si ellos realmente se creen que están llevando la vanguardia y que son creadores de la democracia y de La Paz, porque no presentan algo distinto, porque la republica no funciona y esta viejo francamente. Cuando yo escucho eso lo que escucho es que son un grupo de gente que no quiere compartir sus riquezas, en otras palabras, la republica es un pretexto paran no querer pagar mas impuestos. Por qué no pueden presentar otro modelo? Por qué no pueden dialogar sobre un estado federal? O un estado libre asociado? O aunque sea un arreglo simbólico? O más autonomía? Por qué tiene que ser de repente y ahora? Cual es la necesidad? A quien están tratando de engañar? Se que hay un elemento histórico y los politicos saben tocar las cuerdas de la nostalgia mas bien que nadie, como Yoyoma en el contrabajo. Pero esta crisis provocada me parece mas autoinfligida por una obsesión propia y una codiciada clase política y capitalista. Me podrias acusar de que tengo envidia, o de ignorante, porque no me se la historia. Entiendo que es una historia violenta, una represión y un abuso a una region que siempre ha estado en oposición. Pero no me parece que la union esta en la separación, la union y La Paz esta en la union. Los Estados Unidos intenta con esto y les cuesta y le causa mucho dolor pero no se quitan, y es un trabajo constante con un compromiso por un ideal mas grande mas alla. Pero Lo que sea que les quieres decir es una religion, una narrativa ficticia, cual su única veracidad que tiene es tomar esa narrativa como la verdad absoluta. Y yo francamente no creo mucho en que exista una verdad absoluta, la única verdad que yo creo es la De Dios, el proveedor de amor que es el gobernador de la energía. Todo lo demas me huele a pescau.

También, esta idea de independencia catalán me un mal olor a tribalismo, a supremacia racial, que el se declare que es distinto a los demas implica que eres superior a los demas, que tu raza es superior a los demas. Y ya a mi me basta con esta mierda de idea, que tanto auge a tomado en Estados Unidos, y auge a tomado en Inglaterra, en Rusia, en Turquía, y por poco en Francia. Los valores de igualdad y libertad siempre tienen que estar por encima de cualquiera, y lo que me huela a un fundamentalists hay que sacarlo. Como leche podrida.

Por lo tanto, no estoy convencido de esta reclamación de independencia. Me parecen demasiado a los estadistas aqui en Puerto Rico. Propagandistas con sus agendas, como cualquiera. Pero no estoy convencido. Los catalanes son una raza híbrida, no es una raza absoluta. Las opiniones y ideas deberían de contar a mi tanto como a ellos y no ser excluidas. Creo que La Paz prevalece sobre todo.  Su libertad real vendrá cuando ellos aprendan a despejarse del ego de su identidad nacional.

*Sober.* A.A. believes there is an enormous difference between bring dry and being sober. It is not enough to simply abstain. You need to heal and repair the damage to yourself and others. We talk about "white-knuckle sobriety," which might mean, "I'm sober as long as I hold onto the arms of this chair." People who are dry but not sober are on a "dry drunk."
Being dry is not the same as being sober
Alcoholics Anonymous makes a distinction between being dry and being sober.
Sobriety is not simply about abstaining from alcohol use. It is about healing and repairing the damage to yourself and others.

children.content: When you share your work with someone, you're not only gauging his or her reactions to get feedback and validation but you're also co-creating the story you want to create. In an interview with The Paris Review, Karl Ove Knausgaard said that reading every word out loud to his friend Geir Angell Øygarden gave him the inspiration and impetus to complete the masterpiece of his six autobiographical novels. Knausgaard called Øygarden every day to share what he had written, which had amassed to about 5,000 pages in total. Knausgaard stated that that part of the reason was to get the validation that he was good enough to write this. But the more important reason according to him was to explore what the novel might become, and in what directions it could proceed. It was by sharing his work to a trusted friend that Knausgaard could arrive at what he called "a place where literature mattered". That is a place where you're completely exposed so every word you say reveals your true self.
It is by exposing your work consistently and gradually that you get the work done. And[[the most important possible thing you can do is a lot of work]].
You don't need to write an entire story before you share with it someone, but it does help to remember to write with the door closed, rewrite with the door open.
The Paris Review #[[The Paris Review]]

children.content: Hegel believed that wisdom and understanding about humanity and the world will only come fully at a late stage, when looking back on everything that has happened. The owl of Minerva, Hegel is referring to the Roman goddess of wisdom. That is to say, understanding and wisdom will only make sense when we look back at what has already happened, similarly to how someone looks back on the events of a day as night falls. Underlying this belief was Hegel's view of the Spirit or Mind (Geist) as central to understanding the physical world. While influenced by Immanuel Kant, Hegel rejected Kant's view that the noumenal reality lies beyond the phenomenal world. For Hegel, everything is in constant change, and that change takes the form of a gradual increase in self-awareness, our state of self-awareness being fixed by the period in which we live. Hegel retold the history of the world in terms of gradual increases in individual freedom. This is what Hegel meant when he said "The owl of Minerva only flies at dusk." It is only through the experience of life that we can attain wisdom and therefore, how we attain understanding.
Warburton, Nigel. A Little History of Philosophy. Yale University Press, 2011. #[[Nigel Warburton]]

Let's do a proper brain vomit. Hoy estamos al 12 de marzo del 2022. Estoy en mi piso en el ático en calle Montevideo 22. Hay un diluvio. Iba a ir a jugar fútbol pero decidí que mejor no. Entonces aquí estoy, aprovechando este tiempo para poder escribir algo interesante. "Leí" el libro de "Lost time" un libro traducido sobre un soldado polaco en la segunda guerra mundial que fue capturado por los nazis y luego entregado a las fuerzas soviéticas. Creo que de los 14000 o 4000 solo sobrevivieron menos de 500 y el fue uno de ellos. El nació en la aristocracia pero pedió todo, Josep Capziski (??), era un intelectual y un artista contemporáneo de Picasso entre otros. Tenía una fascinación con Proust tanto que se leía y releía el libro. Cuando fue capturado el hacia lecturas a los otros prisioneros de guerra. Y de eso va el libro. El contando la importancia que tuvo Proust en su vida y compartiendo su conocimiento con otro y la importancia de leer Proust.

Now onto other things. Me llamo Robert Sampson, tengo 34 años y mi sueño es escribir una novela. No se porque, bueno, si se porque, pero no se como hacerlo. Es otro tema. Escribir es imaginarse una conversación. Anoche en mi cuarto pensaba que el punto de escribir no es crear algo original, si no que es recontar las historias que a ti te animaron desde joven, aquellos cuentos que te hicieron brincar con entusiasmo, reír, llorar, todo aquello que te conmovía. Es tener una conversación imaginaria con alguien.

Me encantaría poder hacer algo así. Quizás escribir un artículo. Tener periodos estrechos donde no hago nada más que escribir. Sin distracciones, como estoy haciendo ahora.
I think this is something I can get in the habit of. I can spend some of my time reading, like at night before I go to sleep or whenever I have the time. Then I can spend like an hour in the morning writing something that I think will be worth to share and exciting. Then work during the day. I know this all sounds a bit crazy but I like the idea of writing and writing and writing and writing and sharing my thoughts. It is true that writing comes easier for me in English than it does in Spanish. But how do I concentrate my meaning? Write now this is a brain vomit and the idea is to just write everything down and not stop at all until I stay so. So write now we are in March, Spring is coming and I have yet to write something that I would call my darling. I would love to write a story about my grandparents. I would love to write something funny. But I never do it. So what is happening in my life right now? I work for a company that is almost valued at a billion dollars, I make around 40,000 USD a year and hopefully that will change soon. I have a girlfriend who is 24 years old and very attractive and kind, I live in Barcelona. I have hemhroids which I can never spell correctly because I avoid that word at all costs. I do like to read, I spend a lot of my time organizing, cleaning, and polishing my Personal Knowledge Management tool which I currently use called Logseq. I also spend a lot of time reading that I use a tool call Outread so I don't have to spend scrolling with my thumb, and then I use a tool called Instapaper for articles, iBooks for Books and then Readies to store all my highlights which I can then export to my Logseq tool, this all sounds very complicated but the whole reason for this is so that I can recall that information later on and hopefully use it when I want to create something of value. In my Logseq I have divided it into three sections, first I have inbox which means anything that I would like to keep but is not really clean or polished and is just laying there waiting to be sorted. Then there is "Mind Library" which is really a folder of highlights from books, articles, and other media that have also not been cleaned or polished. The idea is to look at these and then see if they can be sorted organized into something else. When they do they go into my Evergreen notes folder. Now when you open the Evergreen notes folder you will see a few other folders like Quotes, Concepts, Story, Beautiful language, Curiosites, Español and so on. These are individual folders to store my notes for each. Now each of the pages here are atomized ideas that I can then pick and choose where I want to put them in. I start with metadata which has the tag - where it is placed. I have this as a kind of taxonomy of ideas so that I know in what category they pertain to, then I add the source where the idea came from and then see if I have any similar pages that go alongside it. Then I separate this with Notes and then the content goes here. It is a basic structure and so far that is all great. Right now it is a factory of ideas, they get assembled, tagged, and packaged and stay there but that is it. They stay there, not much else happens. And I don't know what to do with it. Maybe I'd much rather just write like this free form and see where my mind takes me. Right now I don't know but I would love to take this to the next level, to fall in love with language and to explore the limits of my mind however uncomfortable that might be.

So as far as next challenges, I would like to create cards for every evergreen note that I've created. I would also like to expand my vocabulary in Spanish and English. I would also like to keep things very simple. My goal is to be a fantastic storyteller. Someone that people flock to to be moved and amazed and to inspire others to tell their stories with as much vigor and verve as possible. I say this a lot, I would like to publish a book. It is hard to compete with Netflix, HBO, YouTube, and the Browser. But I will make it my mission to do so. I would like to write more on paper and use my reMarkable tablet (swoosh!).
I would love to copy what others have done. Copying is the way design works. And I would like to use Anki to refresh the ideas that I constantly review. That would be amaze balls.

blocks.page-name: writing is not something you can master

children.content: > "So that's another tricky thing about writing– there's no reliable method. At least I haven't found one. The tricks that you discovered writing the last story don't work for this new one, and so on. **==It's like being a plumber== but every time you show up, the pipes are made of different materials and transport different types of liquid and you're given weird new tools**. And you're drunk. **Part of the job, then, is to ==be cool with that–with the notion that you are never going to 'master' writing==**. **The only mastery is getting increasingly comfortable with the idea that you are never going to be a master**– you are going to be a perennial clueless beginner with every new story, really, for sure. You'd better be, or you'll turn into a hack." – George Saunders

Writing is a matter of sketching and building and arranging what it is in your mind. Once you get something down, it’s now out of you. Even in rough form, you’ve given yourself clay to mold into something interesting and beautiful. That’s writing. Writing is how you complete your thoughts." In this sense, it is not something you get to master like a carpenter. The mastery comes from being comfortable with the idea that writing is not something you can master.
#[[George Saunders]] Source: [How to Write 10,000 Words a Week](https://forge.medium.com/how-to-write-10-000-words-a-week-a7c63d97ea79) - Drew Magary

Connection: George Saunders compares writing to being a plumber who is forced to work with different materials, liquids, and strange tools each time he takes on a new job. The idea is not to approach it as a 'master', but to become comfortable with the discomfort of knowing that you will never truly be a master, because each job requires you to start from scratch. You are not the master, but the handyman who is tasked with sketching, building, arranging, and fixing what is inside your brain.
[[References]]

> Failure in literature means failure in real life. It means justifying your craft when your friends and loved ones have careers to uphold, mortgages to pay, and mouths to feed. When you fail in this way you also fail socially by letting down those around you.

Writing is unlike any other craft because it is something you can't master through repetition. A cabinetmaker, for example, achieves mastery over his or her craft by practicing the same thing over and over. A writer, on the other hand, needs to start from scratch every time. This is inconceivable for a cabinetmaker. In fact, [[writing is not something you can master]] because it requires no skill and no technique. **==The only thing that matters when it comes to writing is getting to the core of the self.==** So you cannot practice it, you can only fail at it. **What you are failing it as getting at the core of the self, and the more you do it, the more it hurts.** You need the belief that you are capable of getting to the core of self while also recognizing that you are far from it. So [[the most important possible thing you can do is a lot of work]].
It is not something you can master because writing requires that you get to the core of the self. Which is not something you can 'master' through repetition, but by failing over and over again.

blocks.page-name: productivity hacks are like a dog chasing its tail

children.content: What are the ideologies that fuel and shape our understanding of time management? How does our desire for total control shape our day to day decisions? What impact does this have on our emotional wellbeing? The productivity industrial complex is a lot like an ouroboros, a dog chasing its tail. The more you try to optimize your time and “get shit done”, the more likely you will feel drained and unfulfilled at the end of your day. Burkeman argues that letting go of the expectations of productivity by accepting your finitude–the fact that you will die and there’s nothing you can do about it–you can begin to recognize that the desire for total control is an illusion. The more that idea sinks in, the more you can see the bigger picture and limit your activities to what’s within your limited control. Burkeman calls this the “paradox of limitation”. The more you try to control something, the less you can control it. But the more you accept you can’t control everything, the more you will be able to have your own sense of control.
Burkeman, O. (2021). Four Thousand Weeks: Time Management for mortals. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. #[[Oliver Burkeman]]

blocks.page-name: people cannot learn if they are not victims to their own mistakes

children.content: A Bob Rubin trade serves to show how information asymmetries can have catastrophic effects in our society. Bankers like Bob Rubin benefitted from concealing explosive risks which helped him net over a hundred million dollars in bonuses for the decisions that led to the total collapse of the global economy. In a Bob Rubin trade, the profits are passed on to the individual while the losses get passed on to society. A Bob Rubin trade is problematic because rather than bringing bankers to justice for their negligence and greed, they instead got rewarded through taxpayer bailouts. A Bob Rubin trade reminds us that society cannot grow if its decision-makers do not learn to face up to the consequences of their actions. It creates unfairness since the decision-maker is eliminating all the risk and passing it on to others which enables them to make reckless decisions. The message of Bob Rubin is that people cannot learn if they are not victims to their own mistakes. Bob Rubin trades are not exclusive to banking; we can see them everywhere. For instance, entrepreneurs are reliant on employees, not because of the work they produce, but because they bear the risks when shit hits the fan. The employer keeps the profits and passes the losses to the employee.
Taleb, Nicholas Nassim. "Skin in the Game: Hidden Asymmetries in Daily Life". 2017 #[[Nicholas Nassim Taleb]]

Write fiction as poetic astrophysicist.

I was there when the star last bathed the universe in its light. It was a while ago but I was there. Thick flashes of gas ripped right through me. For an outsider, I must have looked frozen. Sealed like a cast of sculpted stone in a museum. But I was very much alive. A wafer like disc kept pounding and growing and while I should have been terrified out my wits, the sound kept lulling me in with its cradle song. Time had become stuck and had no purpose. But Twenty years had passed by and there isn’t a day that goes by that I don’t think about that awful and beautiful day. Now all there is darkness. No flicker of light, no nation, no birds, no dinner time, no sex, no peace, no war, no happiness, no sadness, no family, no earth, no love, no hate. It was all just permanently decoded and unusable. A pile of sand floating in gelatinous pool. A mucous substance. It unlocked something special. While I lost sight, the ability to hear, touch, smell, and see, I gained so much more. The world or whatever it was now called suddenly became 4 dimensional. Everything accelerated faster than the speed of light, and I was right there in the middle. A dark cocoon wrapped itself around me like a sour grape. The universe appeared like diamond crusted burst of rays drizzling in every direction with its infectious spasm. But I knew this was punishment. Nature’s punishment for having starred deep into its vulnerable core. It’s shame. Disintegrating me in a flash would have been too easy. No, this was retribution in its cruelest form. Freezing time and deleting the dash with its last piece of information unscathed, to stare at the compressed rubric that stands as a forgotten monument, twirling like a ballerina waving to the night sky. The loudest scream in the world felt like huffing hot air on a glacier.
Three pillars of life: relationships, confidence, and knowledge.

*What is "Juche"?*
*Juche* is [the official ideology of North Korea](https://palladiummag.com/2022/06/15/environmentalism-in-one-country/), formulated by Kim Il-Sung, who first used the term publicly in 1955 and elaborated it in a speech in 1965. In its original form *Juche* combined the economics of Marxist-Leninism with the rhetoric of nationalism and national exceptionalism. The strategic aim of *Juche* is the self-sufficiency of North Korea. *Juche* is commonly translated as "self-reliance", "autonomy", or "independence", though its etymological roots suggest something closer to "subjectivity".

*What is the origin of the term "Aryan"?*
"Aryan" is derived from the [Sanskrit word "arya"](https://newlinesmag.com/essays/the-realm-of-the-devil-and-the-destroyers-of-rome/), meaning "noble". Some Sanskrit speakers in the 5th-4th centuries BC may possibly have referred to themselves as "Aryans", but the term acquired its modern usage as an imagined racial category only in 19th century, in the works of French and German scholars who wrongly believed that it had been the term generally used by early Indo-Europeans to describe themselves. They may also have been attracted by the similarity between "arya" and *Ehre, *the German word for "honour".

children.content: Full quote: "To tell yourself that every second not spend doing your work, or working on yourself, is a waste of your gift." "Once we fight this emotional and egotistical impulse, the canvas strategy is easy. The iterations are endless. Maybe its coming up with ideas to hand over to your boss. Find people, tinkers, up-and-comers to introduce them to each other. Cross wires to create new sparks. Find what nobody else wants to do and do it. Find inefficiencies and waste and redundancies. Produce more than anyone and give your ideas away. "The person who clears the path ultimately controls its direction, just as the canvas shapes the painting."

Ryan Holiday shares example of an anteambulo, a position in Ancient Rome where a person would stand in front of a patron anywhere they traveled, making way and communicating messages to make the patron's life easier. In essence, this is the job of a writer. When you clear the path for your reader, you clear the path for yourself. It is in this spirit of service, of being of service to others, that you will honor your reader. When you remember that [[reading is a transaction]], your mind becomes powerfully concentrated in clearing the path.
This is also why Stephen King believes that [[novels are written one word at a time]].
Holiday, R. (2016). Ego is the enemy. Profile Books. #[[Ryan Holiday]]

Este ensayo es una reseña sobre el libro de Emma Cline que se llama The Girls, que se trata sobre las mujeres que siguen una secta semejante a la de Manson en los 60s. Ya han pasado 40 años está viviendo en casa de un amigo y la protagonista siente un ruido en la parte de atrás, es el hijo del amigo. Está con la novia y Evie, la protagonista está asqueada de ver cómo la novia mira al novio indiferente.

Emma Cline es de la misma generación de Luna Dunham, y el de título de Cline se parece bastante a la de Dunham. Ambas proponen una visión de ser niña, la de Cline es: si te encojonas eres una loca, si no reaccionas eres una bicha. También dice pobre niñas, el mundo las infla con la promesa de amor, lo mucho que lo necesitan y lo poco que muchas de ellas tendrán. Evie encuentra la secta como un escape del malestar femenino de inseguridad y necesidad.

Cline ficcionaliza los asesinatos de Manson, haciendo referencia menos a Helter Skelter- el plan delusional de Manson para crear una guerra de razas en Estados Unidos. Este personaje se llama Mitch Russell, y tiene poder porque es un experto en la tristeza femenina. Pero Evie no está encantado con Russell, ella está enamorada de Suzzane que esta enamorada de Russell. Los asesinatos de Manson han sido usado en muchas referencias literarias: Thomas Pynchon en Vice enfoca luego de los 60s, cuando Larry Doc Sportello le pide a su novia si se puede poner una peluca como Lynette "Squeaky" Fromme, la que intentó asesinar a Gerald Ford. John Waters en Pink Flamingo sátira a las mujeres de Manson. Didion también y atribuye que el final de los sesenta culminó en agosto 9, 1969. Volviendo al libro, Evie propone que poco ha cambiado de ser una niña hoy. Una chica todavía no tiene agencia, buscando complacer y esta dictada por fantasía masculina (si, pero hay abuso de parte femenina también). Ser mujer tampoco ofrecer un respiro. En 1963, cuando salió Bell Jar y Mystique Femenino trataba sobre Asfixiado en "dreamscape" para ayudar destruir la mitología falsa sobre qué hace una mujer feliz. Asume que estos personajes últimamente viven en su casas con sus madres

children.content: Existentialism has its origins in the philosophical field of phenomenology. The leading thinker for the phenomenologist was **Edmund Husserl**. His message was don't waste time interpreting things and don't waste time wondering it they are real. Look at whatever is presenting itself to you and describe it as precisely as possible. **Raymond Aron**, specifically, had learned about it after studying in Berlin and was now sharing his insights with his friends Sartre and Beauveoir.

In __The Plague__, Albert Camus writes, “But, you know, I feel more fellowship with the defeated than with saints. Heroism and sanctity don't really appeal to me, I imagine. What interests me is being a man.” Camus wants the reader not to pursue heroism for the sake of heroism, not to be concerned with fame or recognition of others, but rather pursue one's existence and examine what it means to be a man. This is also an idea that Knausgaard frequently brings up.
The defeated is part of what brings closeness in [[a day in the life of a cop]].

I'm sitting by the side chapel with black Christ at the Cathedral of Barcelona. I thought about going back to write but if this is a center for prayer and if writing is my own form of prayer then I might as well just write here instead. The Cathedral of Barcelona is the most hauntingly beautiful pieces of gothic architecture I have seen. I pulled my chest against the cold wall and stared straight the 90 degree vertical wall up to the rooftop. It's beautiful. Death is so near. I was planning on going back to the hotel room because I was a bit depressed, I had a chicken burger at Bocoa which is beautifully executed and designed (even the cows are cool about being slaughtered for burgers!). And felt lost so I decided to walk for a bit. I've come to the conclusion that one of the things that mKes Europe so great is that all cities are designed around churches, aka faith, so that anyone lost anywhere who decides to go for a walk and meander will naturally come to a place of faith. How amazing is that? Tell me anywhere else, esp in US, where you can accidentally stumble upon a place of faith, well designed cities, I think this has done more to save lives that anything. The other great thing about the cathedral is that inside is a labyrinth. There are a lot of things I just sort of stumbled, like I was walking and one of the security guards sort of forced me into an elevated that I had no idea would take me to the roof (I don't read those ducking brochures man!), the rooftop is beautiful but sketch. Once down the interior gardens there are geese I found my unique spot in the cathedral, it is the most sacred place for me. It is the chapel of St Josep by Anonim, from the 13th century. It is haunting, there are lit candles it sits on a dark corner of the church and restored and yet forgotten. It is bittersweet, it tells something that I can't quite figure out, it's so mysterious and I think that's why I love it so much. The other surprise in the cathedral by the garden is the small museum within it. When I came in, for some reason, Oasis was playing in the background. In the museum there is the Piedad de Desplè, an oil on canvas that depicts the suffering of Christ and the Holy Mother. Not to offend but Holy Mother resembles that of a sad emoji face. Christ appears to have a shirt, and there is a very stranger looking dude on the right. He has small arms and their hurdles together which makes it look like he is deformed, this is apparently one of the most appealing pieces of the museum in the church. It is impressive how this was made in the 15th century. I've come to think of it as people having talent and believing that it is their work to represent Christ in some visual form of another, that that is their God given mission. I think of how I myself am a product of that, my ancestors immigrants, having left their own home, a home that has been theirs for centuries and coming to a new place, because of a God given mission. The millions that were butchered because they felt it was to safeguard their God given mission, when in reality, what they were experiencing was fear, something I would sure feel, but instead they decided to put a name on it. And it worked, a belief in a higher power succeeded. So today, I put my faith in you.

blocks.page-name: offer multiple interpretations to activate the reader

children.content: In an interview with the Paris Review, Michael Haneke shared how he grabs the attention of his viewers. "There are always multiple interpretations because I’m trying to make my viewers have to pick an option. That is my attempt to activate the viewer—I present my stories in a relatively open way so as to coerce the viewer to contribute his own reflections. That, by the way, is also the most respectful behavior toward the viewer." One of the things that make Haneke a powerful storyteller is that, instead of guiding you towards a satisfying conclusion, he simply connects dots within the plot but leaves the rest open for interpretation. Haneke calls this "respectful behavior", by which I think he means involving them in the film and making them a key part of the conversation. His films then are about having the courage to arrive at your own conclusion.
When you [[use ambiguity to open up multiple interpretations in your story]], you co-create the story with the reader. This works well because [[your mind is a story creation machine]].
The Paris Review Art of Fiction with Michael Haneke #[[The Paris Review]]

In his book, Johan Hari describes an extreme case of food poisoning in Vietnam. Hari pleaded with doctors to give him something that would bring relief to his nausea. But the doctors refused. As the translator explained to Hari, “The doctor says you need your nausea. It is a message, and we must listen to the message. It will tell us what is wrong with you.” This experience paved the foundation for Hari's understanding of how to deal with depression and anxiety. And the wisdom imparted by that experienced can be summed into the following, listen to the pain. As Hari says, "your distress is not a malfunction. It is a signal–a necessary signal" and goes on to say that "pain isn't your enemy...it's your ally–leading you away from a waste life and pointing the way toward a more fulfilling one." So pay attention to your pain.
Hari, J. (2018). Lost connections: Why you're depressed and how to find hope. Bloomsbury. #[[Johan Hari]]

blocks.page-name: FATCA made the US a tax haven

children.content: The Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) is a 2010 United States federal law passed by Congress and supported by Obama and at then Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner. FATCA was celebrated as a triumph against foreign tax evasion because it required that foreign financial institutions and other non-financial foreign entities report on the foreign assets held by their U.S. account holders. Thus, individuals could no longer stash their money in accounts to avoid paying taxes while the rest paid taxes at home. While this proved useful for Americans looking to hide their money abroad, it also created incentives for people abroad to hide their money in the U.S. thanks to attractive tax loopholes.
Bullough, Oliver. Moneyland: Why Thieves And Crooks Now Rule The World And How To Take It Back. Profile Books, 2019. #[[Oliver Bullough]]

blocks.page-name: margin of safety protects you from uncertainty and vulnerability

children.content: One way to avoid ruin is by having room for error, or margin of safety. Having a margin of safety raises the odds of success at a given level of risk by increasing your chances of survival. This comes in many forms, a frugal budget, flexible thinking, and a loose timeline. Basically, it is anything that lets you live happily with a range of outcomes. As Housel writes , "the purpose of margin of safety is to render the forecast unnecessary." Margin of safety—you can also call it room for error or redundancy—is the only effective way to safely navigate a world that is governed by odds, not certainties. And almost everything related to money exists in that kind of world.Margin of safety helps us stay sane when things go to shit. You may survive physically, but you might be destroyed emotionally.
Housel, M. "The Psychology of Money: Timeless Lessons on Wealth, Greed, and Happiness" September 2020 #[[Morgan Housel]]

blocks.page-name: a beat is the atomic unit of every story

children.content: A beat is described as an exchange of behavior in action/reaction. It is the atom and the basic building block that gives shape and form to a story. A successive series of beats will give form to a scene. A successive series of scenes will give form to an act. And a consequence of an act, which is [[an act marks an irreversible change in the story]], will give shape and form to a story. Mckee reveals that while the words you use matter to telling a compelling story, what matters more is the pattern of events created by this sequence and the meaning behind them. By looking at the composition of beats in a story, you can have better insight into the patterns and motivations for how and why things happen in the world.
McKee, Robert. Story: Substance, Structure, Style and the Principles of Screenwriting. , 1997. #[[Robert McKee]]

The intimate interrupter is a saboteur. I fall victim to this whenever I open my browser to look for LinkedIn notifications, to watch another episode of the Sopranos. It's bizarre to think these are activities I spend time doing yet assign no value, whereas that I spend little time doing that which I value the most.
Pay attention to this voice, be aware of it because [[listen to your nausea]].

> Creative work needs solitude. It needs concentration, without
interruptions. It needs the whole sky to fly in, and no eye watching until
it comes to that certainty which it aspires to, but does not necessarily
have at once. Privacy, then. A place apart–to pace, to chew pencils, to
scribble and erase and scribble again.
But just as often, if not more often, the interruption comes not from
another but from the self itself, or some other self within the self, that
whistles and pounds upon the door panels and tosses itself, splashing into
the pond of meditation. And what does it have to say? That you must phone
the dentist, that you are out of mustard, that your uncle Stanley’s birthday
is two weeks hence. You react, of course. Then you return to your work, only
to find that the imps of idea have fled back into the mist.
It is this internal force–this **intimate interrupter**–whose tracks I would
follow. The world sheds, in the energetic way of an open and communal place,
its many greetings, as a world should. What quarrel can there be with that?
But that the self can interrupt the self–and does–is a dark and more
curious matter.

In Blue Pastures,Mary Oliver describes the "intimate interrupter", that inner voice that comes from a self within the self and "whistles and pounds upon the door panels and tosses itself, splashing into the pond of meditation." We listen to the intimate interruptor because the reality of facing your limitation is painful. Burkeman says, "whenever we succumb to distraction, we're attempting to flee a painful encounter with our finitude–with the human predicament of having limited time, and more especially, in the case of distraction, limited control over that time, which makes it impossible to feel certain about how things will turn out... when you try to focus on something you deem important, you're forced to face your limits, an experience that feels especially uncomfortable precisely because the task at hand is one you value so much." Distractions are nothing but a desperate attempt to seek relief from discomfort.
Oliver, M. (1995). Blue Pastures. Harcourt Brace.
Burkeman, O. (2021). Four Thousand Weeks: Time Management for mortals. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. #[[Oliver Burkeman]]

blocks.page-name: optimism is the belief that the odds are in your favor

children.content: Optimism is the belief that the odds of a good outcome are in your favor. You will still experience setbacks along the way, but an optimist believes the end result will justify the means. Pessimism is the opposite. It is the belief the odds of a good outcome are not in your favor. By harboring this view, you will likely reduce your expectations about the future to protect yourself, and therefore narrow the gap between possible outcomes. Pessimism is psychologically seductive, since it shields you from the pain of experiencing a setback and allows you to control and manage your expectations. Expecting things to be bad is the best way to be pleasantly surprised when they're not.
Housel, M. "The Psychology of Money: Timeless Lessons on Wealth, Greed, and Happiness" September 2020 #[[Morgan Housel]]
